questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the dental clinic with complaints of altered sensation in the lower lip and chin on the right side. The patient recently underwent a third molar extraction on the right side. On examination, there is evidence of sensory loss in the affected region. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected during the extraction procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mandibular nerve (V3):

  • The altered sensation in the lower lip and chin on the right side following a third molar extraction is suggestive of injury to the inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3). The mandibular nerve is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V) and provides sensory innervation to the lower face, oral cavity, and part of the tongue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Maxillary nerve (V2): The maxillary nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the upper face, and its branches are not typically involved in lower lip and chin sensation.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve (V): The trigeminal nerve consists of three divisions: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3). The mandibular division is the one primarily associated with the symptoms described.

Option D - Facial nerve (VII): The facial nerve is not involved in sensory innervation of the lip and chin; it is responsible for motor function of the muscles of facial expression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a fall from a height. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the right clavicle. An x-ray was taken. Which of the following structures is at risk for injury in this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brachial plexus:

  • The given x-ray shows a clear case of Mid shaft fracture of clavicle.
  • A midshaft fracture of the clavicle can pose a risk to the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the upper limb. The brachial plexus runs in close proximity to the clavicle, and a fracture can result in injury to the nerves, leading to neurological symptoms such as pain, numbness, or weakness in the arm.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subclavian artery: The subclavian artery is located deeper and is not typically at risk in a midshaft clavicle fracture.

Option C - Cephalic vein: The axillary vein is located more inferiorly and is not directly in the path of a midshaft clavicle fracture.

Option D - Suprascapular nerve: The suprascapular nerve travels over the superior border of the scapula and is not directly at risk in a midshaft clavicle fracture.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with a complaint of shoulder pain and the noticeable protrusion of her scapula on certain movements. On examination, the following finding is seen.



Which of the following conditions is most likely causing the observed finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Long thoracic nerve palsy:

  • The finding in the picture is scapular winging.
  • Scapular winging, the abnormal protrusion of the scapula from the thoracic wall, is often associated with dysfunction of the long thoracic nerve. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which plays a crucial role in stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall during arm movements. Damage to the long thoracic nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, leading to scapular winging.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Rotator cuff tear: While a rotator cuff tear can cause shoulder pain and weakness, it is not typically associated with scapular winging.
  • Option C - Suprascapular nerve entrapment: Suprascapular nerve entrapment may result in weakness in the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles but is not a common cause of scapular winging.
  • Option D - Subscapularis muscle weakness: Subscapularis muscle weakness alone is unlikely to cause scapular winging.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with weakness in his right leg and difficulty walking. On examination, there is evidence of a steppage gait. When asked to evert the foot, the patient exhibits significant weakness. Which nerve is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct C - Deep fibular (peroneal) nerve:

  • Foot eversion is primarily controlled by the muscles innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. These muscles include the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes and inverts the foot. Weakness or paralysis of the deep fibular nerve can result in foot drop, characterized by difficulty lifting the foot and a steppage gait.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve primarily innervates muscles that plantarflex and invert the foot and is not associated with foot eversion.

Option B - Common fibular (peroneal) nerve: The common fibular nerve bifurcates into the deep and superficial fibular nerves. The deep fibular nerve is responsible for foot inversion.

Option D - Superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve: The superficial fibular nerve innervates muscles involved in foot dorsiflexion but is not the primary nerve responsible for foot eversion.

questions.text: During an arthroscopic examination of the shoulder, a tear is identified in a muscle that plays a crucial role in stabilizing the shoulder joint and is part of the rotator cuff. This muscle is located on the posterior aspect of the scapula and contributes to the external rotation of the shoulder. Which muscle is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Infraspinatus:

  • The muscle located on the posterior aspect of the scapula that contributes to the external rotation of the shoulder and is part of the rotator cuff is the infraspinatus. Tears or injuries to the infraspinatus can lead to shoulder instability and weakness in external rotation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Subscapularis: The subscapularis is located on the anterior aspect of the scapula and is responsible for internal rotation of the shoulder.

Option C - Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus is located on the superior aspect of the scapula and is primarily involved in the initiation of shoulder abduction.

Option D - Teres minor: While the teres minor is also involved in external rotation, it is not the muscle primarily located on the posterior aspect of the scapula and considered part of the rotator cuff.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with weakness and numbness in the shoulder region following a traumatic injury. On examination, there is weakness in abduction and external rotation of the arm. Sensation over the lateral aspect of the shoulder is also diminished. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Axillary nerve:

  • The clinical presentation of weakness in abduction and external rotation of the arm, along with sensory deficits over the lateral aspect of the shoulder, is indicative of damage to the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, which are responsible for these movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm and forearm, and its dysfunction would result in different patterns of weakness.

Option C - Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, and its involvement would lead to weakness and sensory deficits in the hand and fingers.

Option D - Median nerve: The median nerve innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm and muscles in the thenar eminence of the hand. It is not typically associated with shoulder abduction or external rotation deficits.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of falling onto an outstretched hand. Localized tenderness is found in the given region.



On examination, there is swelling and pain during axial compression of the thumb metacarpal. Which bone is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Scaphoid:

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a depression on the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand, formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis. Tenderness in this region following a fall onto an outstretched hand is concerning for a scaphoid fracture. The scaphoid is prone to fractures, especially in traumatic incidents, and its location makes it susceptible to injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located near the base of the thumb but is not typically associated with the anatomical snuffbox or the characteristic tenderness described.

Option B - Triquetrum: The triquetrum is one of the carpal bones located on the ulnar side of the wrist and is not directly related to the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C - Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone, and its involvement is not associated with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Imaging studies reveal degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Which structure within the basal ganglia is primarily affected in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Putamen:

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. In the basal ganglia, the putamen is primarily affected in Parkinson's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Caudate nucleus: The caudate nucleus, along with the putamen, is part of the striatum. While the caudate is involved in motor and cognitive functions, it is not the primary site affected in Parkinson's disease.

Option C - Globus pallidus: The globus pallidus is part of the output pathway of the basal ganglia and is affected in disorders such as Huntington's disease, but it is not the primary site of degeneration in Parkinson's disease.

Option D - Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is involved in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia. Lesions or abnormalities in this nucleus can lead to movement disorders, but it is not the primary site affected in Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient undergoes a skin biopsy to investigate a connective tissue disorder. Histological examination reveals thick, coarse collagen fibers that are resistant to stretching. Which type of collagen is most likely predominant in the affected tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Type I collagen:

  • Type I collagen is the most abundant and widely distributed collagen in the body. It is known for providing strength to tissues and is particularly prevalent in tendons, skin, bone, and other connective tissues. Histologically, Type I collagen fibers are thick, coarse, and highly resistant to stretching.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Type II collagen: Type II collagen is primarily found in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye. It contributes to the structural integrity of these tissues but is not associated with the characteristics described in the question.

Option C - Type III collagen: Type III collagen is often found in reticular fibers and is associated with tissues requiring elasticity, such as blood vessels and skin. However, it is not known for its resistance to stretching as observed in the described case.

Option D - Type IV collagen: Type IV collagen is a major component of basement membranes. It is not associated with the thick, coarse fibers characteristic of the tissue described in the question.

questions.text: A 38-year-old tennis player complains of pain on the lateral aspect of their elbow during backhand strokes and while gripping objects. On examination, there is tenderness over the lateral epicondyle, and resisted wrist extension reproduces the pain. Which of the following anatomical structures is primarily affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lateral epicondyle:

  • This patient is presenting with symptoms consistent with lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow. Tennis elbow is characterized by pain and tenderness over the lateral epicondyle of the humerus, which is exacerbated by gripping activities and resisted wrist extension.
  • Tennis elbow, or lateral epicondylitis, involves inflammation or microtears in the extensor tendon attachment on the lateral epicondyle. The pain is typically felt during activities that involve gripping or wrist extension.
  • In tennis elbow, the extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle and its tendon attachment to the lateral epicondyle are commonly affected. Overuse or repetitive strain on this area, as seen in activities like tennis backhand strokes, can lead to this condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medial epicondyle: Pain and tenderness on the medial aspect of the elbow would be more indicative of medial epicondylitis or golfer's elbow, which involves the flexor-pronator tendons.

Option B - Ulnar nerve: Ulnar nerve involvement typically presents with symptoms such as tingling or numbness along the medial aspect of the forearm and hand, and weakness in grip strength. It is not the primary structure affected in tennis elbow.

Option C - Radial head: Radial head involvement is more associated with radial tunnel syndrome, and it would present with pain and tenderness over the proximal forearm, not the lateral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with an unintentional weight loss, fatigue, and generalized edema. On examination, there is evidence of ascites, and physical findings suggest hypoalbuminemia. Further investigation reveals elevated serum cholesterol levels. Which anatomical structure is primarily responsible for draining excess interstitial fluid and dietary lipids from the lower extremities and abdomen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thoracic duct:

  • The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body and is responsible for draining excess interstitial fluid, dietary lipids, and immune cells from the lower extremities, abdomen, left side of the thorax, left upper limb, and the left side of the head and neck. It plays a crucial role in maintaining fluid balance, transporting chyle (a milky fluid containing dietary lipids), and returning it to the bloodstream.
  • In the presented case, the patient's symptoms of unintentional weight loss, fatigue, generalized edema, ascites, and elevated serum cholesterol levels suggest a disruption in the drainage of chyle by the thoracic duct. This could lead to the accumulation of lipids and proteins in the interstitial spaces, causing hypoalbuminemia and edema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D - Cisterna chyli, Right lymphatic duct and Spleen: Are not directly involved in draining excess interstitial fluid and dietary lipids from the lower extremities and abdomen

questions.text:
A 28-year-old patient presents with weakness in forearm extension following a fall. On examination, there is sensory loss over the dorsal aspect of the hand. The following presentation is seen:



Which anatomical structure is most likely injured, resulting in these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Radial nerve:

  • The radial nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles that extend the forearm, wrist, and fingers. A fall or injury can lead to damage or compression of the radial nerve, resulting in wrist drop and weakness in forearm extension. Additionally, sensory loss over the dorsal aspect of the hand is characteristic of radial nerve injury.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D - Axillary nerve, Musculocutaneous nerve and Ulnar nerve: Are not associated with the described symptoms. The axillary nerve is involved in shoulder abduction, the musculocutaneous nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior arm, and the ulnar nerve is responsible for sensations in the medial part of the hand and motor function of certain hand muscles.

questions.text: The parents of a 13-month-old child took her to the clinic for a general examination. The infant couldn't speak "papa," but other developmental milestones were normal, according to the doctor. In which month does the relevant milestone development take place?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 9 months:

  • A 9-month-old infant starts babbling bi-syllables without meaning (mama, papa).

  • Other milestones at 9 months:

    • Child waves bye-bye

    • Assisted pincer grasp

    • Standing with support

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 6 months:

  • Milestones achieved at 6 months:

    • Mono-syllables babbling (ma, ba, da)

    • Mirror play appears

    • Immature Palmar grasp

Option C - 12 months:

  • Milestones achieved at 12 months:

    • Speaks 2-3 words with meaning

    • Kisses on request

    • Plays a simple ball game

 

Option D - 18 months:

  • At 18 months, the baby starts to speak a vocabulary of 8–10 words with meaning.

questions.text: The mother of a 3-year-old child complains to the pediatrician that her son looks "swollen." When examined, the patient weighs 9 kg and has pitting edema, moon face, reddish hair, hepatomegaly, dry skin, and a low appetite. Which of the following conditions will lead to complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hypoglycemia:

  • The patient suffers from severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

  • Based on the findings of hepatomegaly, moon face, edema, and poor appetite suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

  • In SAM, hepatic gluconeogenesis is reduced, and energy production from substrates like galactose and fructose is impaired. This increases the risk of hypoglycemia.

  • Intestinal absorption of nutrients and glucose is also markedly reduced in children with or without edematous malnutrition.

  • Blood glucose clearance is reduced along with insulin levels, but these changes do not increase blood glucose levels.

  • Hypoglycemia increases both morbidity and mortality in these patients.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Neurogenic shock:

  • In severe acute malnutrition patients, there is an alteration in gut barrier function and mucosal immune function, and reduced production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

  • Lymph nodes, tonsils, and thymus are atrophic and they are at increased risk of developing septic shock.

  • There is no role of neurogenic shock in SAM.

Option B - Hypernatremia:

  • Sodium pump activity is reduced at the cellular level, which leads to increased cellular membrane permeability that results in an increase in intracellular sodium.

Option C - Hyperthermia:

  • The basal metabolic rate in severe acute malnutrition is reduced to 30%.

  • Both generation and heat loss are impaired; thus, the child has hypothermia, not hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of blue coloration of the body within a few minutes of playing. His SpO2 is 78%, Temp: 37.7℃. After squatting, cyanosis disappears. Examination shows a single S2 and RVH pattern on ECG. What are the X-ray findings consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • The given clinical scenario is consistent with the X-ray findings of a ‘Boot Shaped Heart (or) 'Cor En Sabot' appearance’ that is suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • TOF:

    • MC congenital cyanotic heart disease in children

    • 4 Components:

      • Large, non restricted VSD

      • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOT) or pulmonary stenosis (infundibular or subpulmonic>valvular)

      • Overriding of aorta

      • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Incorrect Options:

Option B:

  • The given X-ray finding is Egg on the String Sign appearance which is seen in Transposition of Great Arteries

  • TGA: Pulmonary artery instead of arising from Right Ventricle, arises from left ventricle and aorta instead of arising from left ventricle, arises from right ventricle

Option C:

  • The given X-ray finding is a box-shaped heart seen in the Ebstein anomaly.

Option D:

  • The given X-ray finding is 'Figure 8' or 'snow man' appearance seen in supracardiac TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection)

questions.text: A newborn delivered at 31 weeks gestation and undergoing respiratory distress as a result of prolonged labor has to be admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) shortly after birth; bag and mask ventilation was initiated. The mother's prenatal assessment had been discussed with the doctor; under what circumstances would the bag and mask ventilation need to be stopped promptly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

  • Bag and mask ventilation - Absolute contraindication in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

  • Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia:

    • There is a pleuroperitoneal membrane defect through which the bowel loops herniate into the thorax

    • In bag and mask ventilation,can cause insufflation of the stomach and subsequent extra pulmonary compression of the lungs .This may compromise adequate oxygenation and ventilation

  • Ventilation in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia can be done by placing a nasogastric tube into the stomach for the removal of the air and secretions.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Cleft palate:

  • A cleft palate is a split or opening in the palate.

  • The Cleft palate causes a hole between the mouth and nose.

  • Bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in cleft palate patients

Option B - Umbilical hernia:

  • An umbilical hernia is very common in preterm babies.

  • Bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in the umbilical hernia

Option C - Cleft lip:

  • A cleft lip occurs when the developing facial structure doesn't close completely in an unborn baby.

  • The bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in cleft lip patients

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was admitted to the outpatient department (OPD) after complaining of a fever, cough, and redness in both eyes for two days. The immunization was not finished by the patient according to the National immunization schedule. There are reddish patches on the child's buccal mucosa with a white core. Regarding this condition, which of the following states is true?

choices.text: Most common cause of death is Pneumonia
The fever stops before the onset of the rash

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Most common cause of death is Pneumonia:

  • The described clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of measles.

  • After measles, cell-mediated immunity of the child decreases and child is prone to infections like respiratory infections, pneumonia, diarrhea. So, the most common cause of death in measles patient is Pneumonia

  • Vitamin A is often used in the treatment of measles, it helps in mucosal immunity.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - It follows the iceberg phenomenon:

  • Measles does not follow the iceberg phenomenon.

Option C - The fever stops before the onset of rash:

  • Low-grade fever develops in the prodromal phase of measles.

  • The fever keeps increasing in intensity till the onset of the rash.

  • The fever and other prodromal symptoms of the infection begin to subside after the onset of the rash.

Option D - The incubation period is 10-21 days:

  • The incubation period of measles is 8-12 days

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is admitted to the emergency room after complaining of five days of extreme, all-over body edema. In addition, the patient reports having difficulty breathing when lying down. He continues on to say that sitting upright helps with his dyspnea. The patient has pedal edema, facial puffiness, and periorbital edema, according to a physical examination. The patient has hypoalbuminemia and severe proteinuria, based on a blood and urine examination. Given the patient's present pathology, which medication is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prednisolone:

  • This is a case of nephrotic syndrome in which the child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe generalized swelling of the body for 5 days.

  • The physical examination of the patient reveals periorbital edema, facial puffiness, and pedal edema, which suggest nephrotic syndrome.

  • The drug of choice for a child with first-episode nephrotic syndrome is oral prednisolone.

  • The generalized edema of the patient can be relieved by the administration of diuretics.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Mycophenolate mofetil:

  • Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressant drug.

  • It is used in autoimmune diseases.

  • It is used in relapsing nephrotic syndrome.

Option B - Cyclophosphamide:

  • The drug of choice for steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is Levamisole > cyclophosphamide.

  • SDNS (steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome): 2 consecutive relapses during alternate-day steroid treatment or relapse within 14 days of stopping steroid therapy.

Option D - Cyclosporine:

  • Drugs of choice for steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome are calcineurin inhibitors like cyclosporine and tacrolimus.

  • SRNS (Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome): Inability to induce remission within 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy.

questions.text: The parents of a 7-month-old boy brought him in, complaining of persistent diarrhea after he began receiving a supplemental wheat diet. The infant shows pallor and delayed developmental milestones. The result of a duodenal biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies does not correspond with this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anti Topoisomerase-1:

  • The given duodenal biopsy depicts Villous atrophy.

  • The clinical scenario and biopsy suggestive of Celiac sprue/Celiac disease

  • Immunological factors of celiac disease:

    • Anti TTG (Tissue Trans Glutaminase)

    • Anti Endomysial Antibody (EMA)

    • Anti DGP (Deamidated gliadin peptide)

  • Anti Topoisomerase-1 antibody is associated with Scleroderma

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Anti-TTG antibody:

  • Anti-TTG antibody is associated with Celiac disease

Option B - Anti-endomysial antibody:

  • Anti-endomysial antibody is associated with Celiac disease

Option D - Anti-gliadin antibody:

  • Anti-gliadin antibody is associated with Celiac disease

questions.text: All of the following given below are X-linked recessive disorders, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rett syndrome:

  • Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant inheritance

  • It is a condition more common in girls

  • Most common gene mutation: MECP 2 gene mutation

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder

  • Dystrophin gene is affected in DMD

Option B - Fabry disease:

  • Mode of inheritance: X-linked recessive inheritance

  • It is a Lysosomal storage disorder

Option C - Hunter disease:

  • Mode of inheritance: X-linked recessive inheritance

  • It is a Type II Mucopolysaccharidosis

questions.text: An 8-month-old male child was brought to the pediatrician with the following findings: What is the management plan for the given findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Zinc supplementation:

  • The given image depicts Acrodermatitis Enteropathica

  • It is a genetic disorder caused due to Zinc deficiency

  • Onset: After 6 months of age (Weaning of the child).

    • Triad - DAD

      • D - Dermatitis

      • A - Alopecia

      • D - Diarrhoea

  • Treatment of Zinc deficiency: Zinc supplementation

    • In inherited deficiency like Acrodermatitis Enteropathica: 3 mg/kg/day (lifelong)

    • In acquired cases: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (till the cause is taken care of)

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Vitamin C supplementation:

  • A deficiency of Vitamin C causes Scurvy which is treated by

    • Vitamin C supplementation

    • A diet rich in vitamin C (citrus fruits)

Option C - Calcium supplementation:

  • Deficiency of Calcium leads to

    • Rickets, Increased irritability, Seizures

    • In neonates: Apnea, poor feeding, jitteriness

  • Treatment of hypocalcemia

    • Acute: Inj. Ca gluconate

    • Chronic: Oral calcium supplements

Option D - Iron supplementation:

  • Deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA)

  • IDA is one of the most common nutritional disorders, especially in developing countries like India

  • Treatment of IDA:

    • Iron supplementation: 3-6mg/kg/day for a minimum of 3 months

    • It can be given in the form of Iron tablets, syrups

questions.text: A 5-week-old neonate presents to the pediatric outpatient department due to constipation for the past 3 days. It is associated with abdominal distension, dry skin, and prolonged jaundice. A physical examination is given. Which of the following tests will help to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  T4, TSH assay:

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism.

  • Hypothyroidism presents with constipation, pallor, edematous facies, open posterior fontanel, umbilical hernia, hypothermia, large tongue, rough, dry skin, hypotonia, and large abdomen.

  • Initial investigation of hypothyroidism includes TSH and T4 levels.

  • TSH level is increased, and T4 is decreased in primary hypothyroidism.

  • TSH level is reduced along with T4 levels in secondary hypothyroidism.

  • Other investigations include thyroid ultrasound and evaluation of radionuclide uptake.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Rectal mucosal biopsy:

  • A rectal mucosal biopsy is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease, which presents with constipation in the early neonatal period.

  • Rectal mucosal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Option B - ACTH level:

  • ACTH level is used to identify adrenal diseases such as Cushing’s syndrome and Addison’s disease.

  • It has no role in the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Option D - Upper GI Endoscopy:

  • The patient’s symptoms are consistent with congenital hypothyroidism. Upper GI endoscopy is not typically performed to diagnose congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the ER by his parents with complaints of generalized seizures lasting more than 15 minutes. The boy has an up-rolling of the eyes, unconsciousness, and urinary incontinence. He is afebrile and has had no history of fever. After initial treatment, he is stable but has postictal confusion. His uncle has a known case of epilepsy. Which of the following is the initial drug of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lorazepam:

  • In this case, the child has been suffering from generalized tonic-clonic fits for the last 15 minutes. He has uprolling of his eyes, urinary incontinence, and loss of consciousness. He also has a suggestive family history. Therefore, the initial diagnosis should be status epilepticus.

  • The initial drug of choice for status epilepticus in children is a short-acting benzodiazepine, such as Lorazepam or Midazolam. They are given to abort the ongoing fits.

  • If fits persist, give a phenytoin loading dose (20 mg/kg).

  • 10mg/kg phenytoin can be given if fits persist 5 minutes after giving the loading dose.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Phenobarbitone:

  • Phenobarbitone is a barbiturate used to control many types of seizures.

  • It can be given as a last resort to abort status epilepticus in cases not responding to first and second-line treatment.

Option C - Valproate:

  • Sodium valproate increases GABA activity and decreases glutamate activity.

  • It’s indicated for generalized tonic-clonic seizures and bipolar disorder.

Option D - Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin is given in status epilepticus if the seizures fail to respond to a short-acting benzodiazepine, such as lorazepam or midazolam.

  • It is given as a loading dose of 20mg/kg initially. If this doesn't abort the fit, it's given as a 10mg/kg dose.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has difficulty distinguishing some shades of red and green color on the Ishihara chart, Both his parents have no difficulty in interpreting the Ishihara chart. Of the following, what is the pattern of inheritance of the boy’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - X-linked recessive inheritance:

  • Red-green color blindness has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. In the given case his mother should be a carrier.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autosomal dominant inheritance: Red-Green color blindness does not follow an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance

Option B - Autosomal recessive inheritance: Red-Green color blindness does not follow an Autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance

Option D - Mitochondrial inheritance: Red-Green color blindness does not follow Mitochondria pattern of inheritance

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dehydration does not affect sickling:

  • This statement is false as dehydration exaggerates sickling.
  • All the other options are true regarding the sickling of RBCs.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy presents with cola-colored urine and pedal edema, gives a history of sore throat 2 weeks back which was not treated with antibiotics. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's condition?

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.

2. Streptococcus pyogenes : strains 12 and 4 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show flea bitten appearance.

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1,2 and 3 are true:

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex mediated)

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12 and 4 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show a flea-bitten appearance.

These statements are true regarding PSGN.

Incorrect Options:

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.

This statement is not true, linear immunofluorescence is seen in good pasture syndrome. In PSGN immunofluorescence shows starry sky appearance.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Figure of 8 appearance seen in Blastomycosis
			
			
			1. 

			
			
		
		
			
			B. Crushed ping pong balls seen in pneumocystis Jirovecii pneumonia.
			
			
			2.

			
			
		
		
			
			C. Owl eye appearance seen in Cytomegalovirus pneumonia.
			
			
			3.

			
			
		
		
			
			D. Warthin finkeldey giant cells in measles
			
			
			4.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2:

The images are matched to their right description.

questions.text: Given that Red indicates disease in the pedigree chart, which of the following diseases follow the given inheritance pattern:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Incontinentia pigmenti:

  • Incontinentia pigmenti shows an X-linked Dominant pattern of inheritance and the pedigree chart depicts the same pattern of inheritance.

Incorrect choices:

Option A - Hypertrichosis: Shows Y linked or holandric pattern of inheritance.

Option C - Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: Shows Autosomal dominant, Autosomal recessive and XLR types of inheritance

Option D - Sickle cell anemia: Shows Autosomal Recessive pattern of inheritance.

questions.text:
Consider the following:

LDH, PLAP- Tumor markers are positive.

The gross section shows: Cut potato appearance.

New tumor markers: OCT ¾, SALL 4, NANOG are positive.

These statements are consistent with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Seminoma:

  • In seminoma: LDH, PLAP- Tumor markers are positive.
  • The gross section shows: Cut potato appearance.

  • New tumor markers: OCT ¾, SALL 4, NANOG are positive.
  • Cells show a fried egg appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Teratoma:

Mature teratoma is a benign tumor.

  • Components: It contains various mature tissues, such as cartilage, skin, and glandular tissue.
  • Specific Type: When the mature teratoma is cystic, it is often referred to as a dermoid cyst.
  • AFP - Tumor marker is positive.

Option B - Yolk Sac Tumor:

Also Known As Endodermal Sinus Tumor (EST):

  • Histological Features:
    • Schiller Duval Bodies: Characteristic structures seen in endodermal sinus tumors, resembling glomeruli.
    • Germ Cell Arrangement: Blood vessels surrounded by two rows of germ cells separated by space.
    • AFP and alpha1 Antitrypsin - Tumor markers are positive.

Option D - Choriocarcinoma:

Histological Features:

  • Hemorrhage and Necrosis: Commonly seen in choriocarcinoma, reflecting the aggressive and invasive nature of the tumor.
  • Cytotrophoblast and Syncytiotrophoblast: The tumor is composed of these trophoblastic cells. Syncytiotrophoblasts are multinucleated, and cytotrophoblasts are mononucleated.
  • Beta hCG - Tumor marker is positive.

Correct Option C - Alzheimer’s disease - A Cal:

Incorrect Option:

A. Chronic Inflammation

1. AA
