questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came with complaints of chronic back pain, fatigue, and sudden loss of weight. X-ray of his skull shows punched-out lesions and his peripheral smear shows the following characteristic feature. The intracytoplasmic inclusion body shown is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Russel bodies:

  • Russell bodies are intracytoplasmic collections of immunoglobulins, seen in multiple myeloma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dutcher bodies: Dutcher bodies are intranuclear collections of immunoglobulins, seen in multiple myeloma.

Option C - Auer bodies: Auer rods are needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions that are considered a characteristic feature of acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

Option D - Denk bodies: Seen in alcoholic liver disease, made of cytokeratin. Eosinophilic bodies seen inside hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 15-year-old diagnosed with Burkitt’s Lymphoma undergoing chemotherapy came with nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. His blood reports showed elevated Uric acid and decreased calcium levels. Which of these is the likely explanation for the patient's condition?

choices.text: Patient has developed Tumor Lysis syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Patient has developed Tumor Lysis syndrome:

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a potentially life-threatening medical emergency that can occur as a result of cancer treatment. It is often associated with Burkitt’s Lymphoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Patient is in Sepsis:

Difference in features:

Feature

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS)

Sepsis

Etiology

Rapid destruction of cancer cells (post-treatment)

Systemic response to infection

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Leukocytosis or leukopenia
  • Elevated lactate
  • Coagulation abnormalities

Clinical Manifestations
  • Renal dysfunction - Cardiac arrhythmias - Neurological symptoms
  • Fever or hypothermia
  • Hypotension
  • Organ dysfunction
  • Altered mental status

Renal Dysfunction

Common, due to uric acid precipitation

Common, multifactorial including septic shock

Electrolyte Imbalances

Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia

Electrolyte imbalances may occur

 

Option C - Patient has developed Vit-D deficiency:

 

Feature

Vitamin D Deficiency

Tumor Lysis Syndrome

Etiology

Inadequate sunlight exposure, dietary deficiency, malabsorption

Rapid destruction of cancer cells, often post-treatment

Pathophysiology

Impaired calcium absorption, bone health

Massive release of intracellular contents, leading to electrolyte imbalances and renal dysfunction

Clinical Manifestations

Musculoskeletal symptoms, fatigue, mood changes

Renal dysfunction, electrolyte imbalances, systemic symptoms

Laboratory Findings

Low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels

Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia

Treatment

Vitamin D supplementation

Hydration, allopurinol, electrolyte management, supportive care

 

Option D - Patient has Hypomagnesemia: Hypermagnesemia is seen in patients with tumor lysis syndrome where rapid amount of cellular destruction leads to efflux of multiple ion into the blood stream.

questions.text: A 3 yr old child is brought to the opd with complaints of fever, puffy cheeks since 3 days. Immunization history reveals doses being missed since 14 months of age. Which of the following statements regarding the affected gland is true?

choices.text: 90% of tumors of this gland are malignant
With an increase in age the intraglandular adipocytes are found to decrease
Pleomorphic Adenoma is the most common tumor of this gland

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pleomorphic Adenoma is the most common tumor of this gland:

  • Mumps mostly affects the parotid gland.
  • Pleomorphic Adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 90% of tumors of this gland are malignant:

  • This statement is false. Tumors of parotid are mostly benign (pleomorphic adenoma).
  • 90% of tumors of minor salivary glands are malignant.

Option B - With an increase in age the intraglandular adipocytes are found to decrease:

  • This is not true as the opposite is right, “With an increase in age the adipocyte count increases”.

Option D - This gland is mostly mucinous:

  • Parotid is mostly a serous gland.

questions.text: An infant was brought by his mother with complaints of poor appetite, poor growth, and irritability. The infant's urine smells like burnt sugar. Which of the following is associated with the condition that this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate is an essential coenzyme for the BCKD complex, facilitating the decarboxylation of alpha-keto acids derived from branched-chain amino acids.
  • The deficiency associated with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency.

Incorrect Optinos:

Option A - Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is not associated with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD).

Option B - Cystathionine 𝛃 synthase deficiency: Cystathionine 𝛃 synthase deficiency is associated with homocystinuria.

Option C - α-keto acid carboxylase deficiency: Maple Syrup Urine Disease is an inherited metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of certain amino acids, specifically leucine, isoleucine, and valine. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-keto acid decarboxylase (also known as branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex), which is responsible for the breakdown of these amino acids not α-keto acid carboxylase.

questions.text: All the following are examples of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Succinyl Thiokinase:

  • Succinyl Thiokinase is an example of a substrate-level Phosphorylation step.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Isocitrate Dehydrogenase: Isocitrate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

Option B - Alpha Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase: Alpha Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

Option D - Succinate Dehydrogenase: Succinate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

questions.text: A person working in the paint industry presents with a sudden onset of photosensitivity. What is the most sensitive parameter that can be prescribed by the physician for an early identiﬁcation of lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Elevated zinc protoporphyrin levels:

  • Lead can cause acquired porphyria.
  • Ferrochelatase – Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels – most sensitive marker.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Elevated ALA:

  • Lead inhibits Delta ALA dehydratase
  • Delta ALA dehydratase can result in ALA elevation. But this is not the most sensitive marker.

Option B - Elevated coproporphyrin levels: Elevated coproporphyrin levels is also a marker for lead poisoning but not the most sensitive marker.

Option D - High PBG levels: High PBG levels are seen in acute intermittent porphyria not in lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of back pain and stiffness along with pain in hip and knee joints. On examination pigmentation in the eye and thickening of the ear cartilage were observed. Which of the following will be done as a screening test in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Benedict test:

  • The features of joint pain, and discoloration of the sclera and pinna all point toward the diagnosis of alkaptonuria
  • The screening test is Benedict's test. Then if it is positive, prescribe HPLC with tandem mass spectrometry

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ferric chloride test: Ferric chloride test and Guthrie's test is a screen test for Phenylketonuria.

Option B - Guthrie's test: Ferric chloride test and Guthrie's test is a screen test for Phenylketonuria.

Option D - Cyanide nitroprusside test: Cyanide nitroprusside test is done to detect Homocystinuria.

questions.text: Copper in superoxide dismutase acts as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prosthetic group:

  • Copper in superoxide dismutase acts as a prosthetic group.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Cofactor:

  • A cofactor is a non-protein in a transient dissociated incorporation with the protein part.
  • Examples: Calcium-dependent kinases.

Option C - Apoenzyme:

  • Coenzymes act as recyclable shuttle or group transfer agents.
  • Transfer group from one system to another system such as dolichol

Option D – Coenzymes:

  • All enzymes have a protein part and a non-protein part.
  • Protein part → apoenzyme

questions.text: A 7-month-old child presented with complaints of developmental delay. On examination features of hypotonia and hypothermia are observed. The infant has coarse and frizzy hair. On hair microscopy, Trichorrhexis nodosa is seen. Defect in which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ATP 7A:

  • ATP7A gene is a gene encoding copper-transporting ATPase enzyme.
  • There is impaired copper metabolism, and less copper levels are found in the liver and brain but high copper levels are found in ﬁbroblasts and enterocytes in Menke disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ATP7B gene defect: ATP7B gene defect is seen in Wilson disease.

Option C - LIPA gene defect: LIPA gene defect is seen in Wolman Disease.LIPA is also known as LAL (Lysosomal acid lipase).

Option D - HGPRT enzyme deficiency: HGPRT enzyme deficiency is seen in Lesch Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with hypoglycemia, which does not respond to CR hormone administration. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. Which of the following deficiencies is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glucose-6-phosphatase:

  • The given features are consistent with the diagnosis of VON GIERKE DISEASE. In this disease, there is a deficiency of the enzyme glucose 6 phosphatase. It is the most common glycogen storage disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate reacts in the presence of phosphorylase with aldoses and ketoses to yield disaccharides and ultimately produce glycogen and phosphoric acid. Also called Cori ester.

Option C - Glucose-1,6-diphosphate: Glucose-1,6-diphosphate is the central regulator in glycogen metabolism, glycolysis, amino sugar formation as well as bacterial cell wall and capsule formation.

Option D – Glycosaminoglycans: Glycosaminoglycans are heteropolysaccharides and consist of various sulfate-free and sulfate-containing compounds.Not related to von Girls disease

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago, which was resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely reason that has caused this disease?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - UDPGT enzyme deficiency:

  • In individuals with Gilbert Syndrome, the UDPGT enzyme is less active than normal, accumulating bilirubin in the bloodstream. This can cause episodes of jaundice, a yellowing of the skin, and whites of the eyes, particularly during stress or illness.
  • The diagnosis is made through blood tests that measure total bilirubin levels, unconjugated bilirubin levels, and the bilirubin/albumin ratio. The liver function tests, including AST and ALT, are typically normal.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Multidrug resistance protein 2 mutation: Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is caused by Impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin due to mutation in canalicular multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2).

Option C - Inhibition of fatty acid oxidation: Reye Syndrome results from An acute metabolic disorder resulting in generalized mitochondrial dysfunction due to inhibition of fatty acid oxidation.

Option D - ATP 7B gene mutation: ATP7B gene mutation is seen in Wilson's disease.

questions.text: An athlete experiences a sudden increase in muscle tension during a workout. This increase in tension activates a sensory receptor that plays a crucial role in regulating muscle length. Which of the following physiological mechanisms is primarily associated with this sensory receptor and contributes to the modulation of muscle activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Golgi tendon reflex:

  • The Golgi tendon reflex is a mechanism associated with the regulation of muscle tension and length. Golgi tendon organs, located in the tendons at the junction of muscles and tendons, are activated in response to increased tension or contraction of the muscle. This reflex helps prevent excessive muscle contraction and potential damage by causing muscle relaxation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hering-Breuer reflex: It is associated with the regulation of respiratory rate and is activated by lung stretch receptors.

Option C - Bainbridge reflex: It involves stretch receptors in the atria and is associated with the regulation of cardiac output in response to increased venous return.

Option D - Bezold-Jarisch reflex: It is triggered by stimulation of receptors in the left ventricle and leads to a reduction in heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old right-handed male is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed sudden onset of speech difficulty. The patient is aware of his surroundings and appears frustrated when trying to communicate. On examination, there is weakness in the right side of the face and right upper and lower extremities. Additionally, there is a notable difficulty in initiating speech, with the patient only able to produce a few words at a time, despite having intact comprehension. Which of the following regions is most likely affected in this patient, leading to his expressive aphasia?

choices.text: Broca's area in the left frontal lobe
Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe
Angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe
Primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Broca's area in the left frontal lobe:

  • This patient's presentation is suggestive of a lesion in Broca's area, which is located in the left frontal lobe. Broca's area is crucial for the production of speech, and damage to this area often results in expressive aphasia. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty forming grammatically correct sentences and may struggle to initiate speech.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe: Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe, is associated with receptive aphasia, where patients have difficulty understanding language and may produce fluent but nonsensical speech.

Option C - Angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe: The angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe, is involved in reading and writing processes but is not primarily associated with expressive aphasia.

Option D - Primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe: The primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe, is responsible for processing auditory information but is not directly related to the expressive aspect of language production.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and peripheral edema. On examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated, measuring 10 cm above the sternal angle with the patient in a 45-degree upright position. The patient reports compliance with prescribed medications, including diuretics. In this patient, the elevated jugular venous pressure is primarily indicative of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Right ventricular failure:

  • Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) is often associated with right heart failure. In the context of congestive heart failure, the right ventricle struggles to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to increased venous pressure. This is reflected in the elevated JVP, especially when the patient is in an upright position.


Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased cardiac output: It is unlikely in heart failure, as the heart's ability to pump blood efficiently is compromised.

Option C - Aortic stenosis: It primarily affects the left ventricle and is associated with a different set of clinical findings.

Option D - Hypovolemia: It would typically present with decreased JVP due to reduced venous return.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of cold hands and feet. Upon examination, the physician notes decreased peripheral blood flow and cool extremities. The patient's blood pressure is elevated. Which of the following physiological mechanisms contributes significantly to the observed vasoconstriction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system:

  • Vasoconstriction refers to the narrowing of blood vessels, resulting in reduced blood flow to specific tissues or organs. In the context of hypertension, the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) plays a significant role in vasoconstriction.
  • When blood pressure is elevated, the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidneys release renin, initiating the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor that acts on blood vessels to increase peripheral resistance and elevate blood pressure. This vasoconstrictive effect is particularly evident in the extremities, contributing to the observed symptoms of cool hands and feet in the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased release of nitric oxide: It is not consistent with vasoconstriction. Nitric oxide is a vasodilator, and increased release would lead to vasodilation, not vasoconstriction.

Option C - Inhibition of endothelin-1 production: It is also inconsistent with vasoconstriction. Endothelin-1 is a vasoconstrictor, and its inhibition would lead to vasodilation.

Option D - Stimulation of beta-adrenergic receptors: It generally leads to vasodilation. Beta-adrenergic receptors, when activated, typically result in relaxation of smooth muscle in blood vessels, causing vasodilation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of occasional fatigue and dyspnea. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed. Which of the following components of the ECG represents the duration from the onset of atrial depolarization to the onset of ventricular depolarization, and is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PR interval:

  • The PR interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG) represents the duration from the onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to the onset of ventricular depolarization (beginning of QRS complex). This interval reflects the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel from the atria to the ventricles through the atrioventricular (AV) node.
  • A prolonged PR interval may indicate an abnormal delay in the conduction of the electrical impulse between the atria and ventricles, commonly associated with conditions such as first-degree heart block or atrioventricular block.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - QT interval: It represents the time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization and is not directly related to the atrioventricular conduction.

Option C - RR interval: It is the duration between consecutive R waves and represents the cardiac cycle length. It includes both the depolarization and repolarization phases and is not specific to atrioventricular conduction.

Option D - QRS complex duration: It represents the duration of ventricular depolarization and is not directly related to the PR interval or atrioventricular conduction.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with weakness and palpitations. Laboratory tests revealed the following:
 


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			Results 
			
		
		
			
			Plasma Na
			
			
			130 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			K
			
			
			8.5 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Chloride
			
			
			98 mEq/L
			
		
	



Which of the following mechanisms contributes significantly to the electrolyte impairment in this patient?

choices.text: Enhanced cellular uptake of potassium by insulin
Altered potassium release from damaged cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Impaired renal excretion of potassium:

  • In the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD), impaired renal function is a common cause of hyperkalemia. The kidneys play a crucial role in maintaining potassium balance by excreting excess potassium. In CKD, the reduced glomerular filtration rate impairs the ability of the kidneys to excrete potassium efficiently, leading to elevated blood potassium levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased intake of dietary potassium: It is less likely to contribute significantly to hyperkalemia, as the kidneys can usually adjust potassium excretion based on dietary intake.

Option C - Enhanced cellular uptake of potassium by insulin: It is a mechanism that lowers blood potassium levels and is not a typical contributor to hyperkalemia.

Option D - Altered potassium release from damaged cells: It is a potential cause of hyperkalemia, but in this patient with chronic kidney disease, impaired renal excretion is a more direct and common mechanism.

questions.text: A premature newborn is at risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) due to insufficient surfactant production. Which of the following statements best describes the primary physiological role of pulmonary surfactant in the context of neonatal respiratory function?

choices.text: Enhancement of alveolar capillary blood flow
Stimulation of respiratory centers in the medulla

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Promotion of lung compliance:

  • Pulmonary surfactant is a lipoprotein mixture produced by type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Its primary physiological role is to reduce surface tension at the air-liquid interface within the alveoli. This reduction in surface tension prevents alveolar collapse during expiration, promoting lung compliance and preventing the development of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Enhancement of alveolar capillary blood flow: It is not a direct function of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant primarily affects the physical properties of the alveoli.

Option C - Inhibition of bronchoconstriction: It is not a function of pulmonary surfactant. Bronchoconstriction is more related to smooth muscle activity and bronchodilation.

Option D - Stimulation of respiratory centers in the medulla: It is not associated with the primary role of pulmonary surfactant. The medulla regulates respiratory patterns, while surfactant is involved in maintaining alveolar stability.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). Which of the following physiological processes is primarily responsible for the conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3)?

choices.text: Synthesis by the thyroid follicular cells
Release from the anterior pituitary gland
Uptake of iodide by the thyroid follicular cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Deiodination in peripheral tissues:

  • The conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3) primarily occurs in peripheral tissues through the process of deiodination. Peripheral tissues, such as the liver and kidneys, contain deiodinase enzymes that remove one iodine atom from the outer ring of T4, resulting in the formation of the more active T3 hormone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Synthesis by the thyroid follicular cells: It is not the primary mechanism for the conversion of T4 to T3. T3 and T4 are initially synthesized by the thyroid follicular cells, but T4 is then converted to T3 in peripheral tissues.

Option C - Release from the anterior pituitary gland: It is incorrect. T3 and T4 are released from the thyroid gland, not the anterior pituitary gland.

Option D - Uptake of iodide by the thyroid follicular cells: It is related to the initial synthesis of thyroid hormones, not the conversion of T4 to T3.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. During auscultation, the physician notes a murmur occurring immediately after the second heart sound (S2). Which phase of the cardiac cycle is primarily associated with the occurrence of this murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Isovolumetric Relaxation:

  • The murmur occurring immediately after the second heart sound (S2) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation is often associated with a diastolic murmur that occurs during isovolumetric relaxation.
  • During isovolumetric relaxation, the aortic valve is closed, and the ventricles are in the early phase of diastole. In aortic regurgitation, some blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta during this phase, creating turbulence and the characteristic diastolic murmur.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atrial Contraction: It is not associated with the occurrence of a diastolic murmur. Atrial contraction occurs during late diastole.

Option B - Isovolumetric Contraction: It is part of systole when the ventricles are contracting, and the aortic valve is closed. Aortic regurgitation murmur is diastolic, not systolic.

Option C - Rapid Ejection: It is part of systole when blood is rapidly ejected from the ventricles into the aorta. Aortic regurgitation occurs during diastole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with complaints of unexplained weight gain and increased appetite. She reports feeling hungry even shortly after meals. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of a hormone known to stimulate appetite. Which of the following hormones is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Ghrelin:

  • Ghrelin is a hormone primarily produced by the stomach that stimulates appetite and promotes food intake. Its levels typically rise before meals and decrease after eating. Ghrelin is often referred to as the "hunger hormone" because it plays a key role in regulating hunger and energy balance.
  • In this patient presenting with unexplained weight gain and increased appetite, elevated levels of ghrelin are consistent with the symptoms described.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Leptin: Leptin is produced by adipose tissue and acts to suppress appetite. Low levels of leptin are typically associated with increased appetite.

Option C – Insulin: Insulin regulates blood glucose levels but does not have a primary role in stimulating appetite. Insulin is released in response to elevated blood glucose levels, promoting glucose uptake and storage.

Option D – Adiponectin: Adiponectin is another adipokine produced by adipose tissue, and it has insulin-sensitizing and anti-inflammatory effects. It is not primarily involved in appetite regulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with weakness and spasticity in the lower extremities. On examination, a positive Babinski sign was noted. The symptoms are more pronounced on the left side. Which of the following best characterizes the physiological consequences of an upper motor neuron lesion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypertonia and hyperreflexia:

  • The presence of weakness, spasticity, and a positive Babinski sign in the lower extremities, especially when more pronounced on one side, suggests an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. The physiological consequences of an UMN lesion typically include hypertonia (increased muscle tone) and hyperreflexia (exaggerated deep tendon reflexes).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypotonia and hyporeflexia: Hypotonia and hyporeflexia is not consistent with the findings of an upper motor neuron lesion. UMN lesions typically result in increased muscle tone and reflexes.

Option C - Fasciculations and atrophy: Fasciculations and atrophy is more characteristic of lower motor neuron lesions. UMN lesions do not lead to fasciculations, and atrophy is not an immediate consequence of UMN damage.

Option D - Loss of sensation and paresthesias: Loss of sensation and paresthesias is associated with sensory pathways, and UMN lesions primarily affect motor pathways, resulting in motor symptoms such as hypertonia and hyperreflexia.

questions.text: In a patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which lung volume is most likely to be significantly reduced?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV):

  • Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) often experience air trapping due to increased resistance to airflow, leading to difficulty in exhaling fully. This results in an increase in residual volume and a decrease in expiratory reserve volume (ERV).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tidal Volume (TV): This is the volume of air inspired or expired during normal breathing. In COPD, tidal volume may remain relatively normal.

Option B - Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): This is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal inspiration. While COPD may lead to increased work of breathing, the inspiratory reserve volume may be relatively preserved.

Option D - Vital Capacity (VC): This is the sum of tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume. In COPD, the vital capacity can be reduced due to decreased expiratory reserve volume.

questions.text: What determines the maintenance rate of amoxicillin-clavulanic acid in the treatment of a 23-year-old male with sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for four days?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Total body clearance:

  • This is a case of acute pharyngitis in which the patient presents with complaints of sore throat, dry cough, headache and runny nose for four days.
  • On examination of the throat, there is erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. The doctor prescribed a combination medication of amoxicillin- clavulanic acid twice a day for five days to the patient.
  • Maintenance dose depends on clearance and target plasma concentration.
  • With respect to this case, since targeted plasma concentration is not mentioned, total body clearance is the answer.
  • Amoxicillin and beta-lactams, in general, cause time-dependent killing, and we tend to maintain a dose above the MIC for the maximum time possible.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Volume of distribution:

  • This parameter reflects the apparent space in the body available to contain the drug. While it is important for understanding how the drug distributes in the body, it does not directly determine the maintenance rate of the drug.

Option B - Half-life:

  • The half-life of a drug is the time in which an active drug in the body is reduced to half. It depends upon the metabolism and excretion of a drug.

Option C - Lipid solubility:

  • The solubility of a drug determines its metabolism and the metabolism determines the onset of action of the drug.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to your office with complaints of chronic insomnia. His vital signs are normal. He had never taken any medication for insomnia before. After reviewing his medical history, you decide to prescribe zolpidem. Which of the following is a strong reason to choose zolpidem over a benzodiazepine?

choices.text: Zolpidem does not bind to the GABA receptor
Zolpidem has a slow onset of action
Zolpidem has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Zolpidem has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence:

  • Zolpidem, zaleplon and zopiclone are non-benzodiazepine hypnotics
  • These are hypnotics that lack a muscle relaxant and anticonvulsant effect.
  • These have a negligible effect on REM sleep and do not affect sleep architecture.
  • Zolpidem is a short-acting hypnotic that binds to the GABA receptor and has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence than benzodiazepines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zolpidem does not bind to the GABA receptor:

  • Zolpidem binds to the GABA receptor

Option B - Zolpidem has a slow onset of action:

  • Zolpidem has a rapid onset of action.

Option D - Zolpidem is a strong anticonvulsant:

  • The doses of zolpidem required to produce anticonvulsants and muscle relaxation are 10-20 times higher than the doses required for sedation.
  • This makes zolpidem a weak anticonvulsant and muscle relaxant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been experiencing abdominal pain in the gastric region for the past month. The pain is described as burning, not radiating to the back, worsening within 15 minutes of eating, and accompanied by vomiting that provides partial relief. On examination, the patient exhibits the finger pointing sign, deep tenderness at the epigastrium, and signs of anemia. Additionally, the individual has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol. What might be the likely diagnosis and recommended treatments?

choices.text: Gastric ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Duodenal ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Pancreatic ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Gastro-Esophageal Reflux Disease, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gastric ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advice to stop smoking and alcohol:

  • The patient of gastric ulcer disease presents with the same given symptoms, such as epigastric pain that is burning in character, not radiating to the back, increases with intake of food within 15 minutes, and is associated with vomiting that relieves pain to some extent.
  • The gastric ulcer can cause the stomach lining to bleed, leading to anaemia showing fatigue and pale skin, e.t.c. The gastric ulcer pain is so sharply localized that the patient can easily define it with two or three fingers showing a finger-pointing sign.
  • Smoking and alcohol are the causative agents in this case. Smoking stimulates basal acid output causing gastric ulcers.
  • Treatment options are :
    • PPIs, Proton pump inhibitors e.g. omeprazole, lansoprazole and pantoprazole. Side effects are nausea, headache, Pseudomembranous enterocolitis and bone fractures.
    • H2 receptor antagonists, e.g. ranitidine, cimetidine and famotidine. Side effects are confusion, Neurotoxicity, cardiotoxicity , gynecomastia and nausea.
    • Bismuth compounds. Side effects are blackening of stool, darkening of tongue and encephalopathy.
    • Prostaglandin analogues. Side effects are abdominal pain and diarrhoea.
    • Antacid contains magnesium and aluminium.
  • Lifestyles must be changed, such as quitting smoking and alcohol are necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Duodenal ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • In duodenal ulcers, pain is relieved by taking food and restarts after 2-3 hours. The patients tend to eat more to relieve their pain.

Option C - Pancreatic ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • In pancreatic ulcers, the patient presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back in the interscapular region.

Option D - Gastro-Esophageal Reflux Disease, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • The patient presents with deep pain behind the sternum radiating to the throat.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the impact of a drug on cardiomyocyte contraction, finding that maximal contractility is attainable with drug A. The investigator has evaluated the safety and toxicity profile of the novel drug. Which of the subsequent statements most accurately characterizes phase IV clinical trials?

choices.text: It is done for pediatric drugs
It is done for rare drugs
It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs
It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs:

Phase IV clinical trials:

  • Post-marketing surveillance compares the real-life efficacy to that described in research studies.
  • Safety studies following approval (esp. evaluation of rare and long-term side effects)
  • The study population is many patients with a specific disease after drug approval.
  • The study design is open-label.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is done for pediatric drugs:

  • Phase IV clinical trial includes post-marketing studies. Phase IV trials are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials.
  • They are not just done for pediatric drugs to assess the long-term adverse effects of any drug being sent to the market.

Option B - It is done for rare drugs:

  • Phase IV clinical trials are done for all the approved drugs from phases one to three. Thus include the post-marketing studies of all drugs and assess the long-term adverse effects.

Option D - It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies:

  • Phase I clinical trials are known as human pharmacology and safety studies.
  • Phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages.

questions.text: Biochemical mechanisms of drug resistance are shown in the given figure below. Which of the following is the most important mode of resistance in MRSA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – A:

  • Resistance in MRSA occurs mainly because of altered penicillin-binding proteins.
  • This is marked as "A" in this scenario, wherein the modification of the target site is how MRSA commonly develops resistance.
  • The penicillin-binding proteins like transpeptidase are responsible for linking the peptidoglycan chains in the cell wall of the bacteria

Incorrect Options:

Option B – B:

  • Decreased permeability is the mode of resistance of some gonococci to penicillins

Option C – C:

  • Some organisms produce Beta-lactamases, also known as penicillinase, that degrade the Beta-lactam ring of penicillin if the enzyme encounters it.

Option D - D:

  • Bypass of the metabolism and forming the alternate pathway is a mode of resistance of some organisms to few drugs, not penicillin

questions.text: What is the pertinent information about the drug administered, Pralidoxime, in the case of a 49-year-old man with altered consciousness, bradycardia, hypotension, sweating, and constricted pupils, who received the medication after being found on the ground by his wife?

choices.text: It should be started after 24 hours of poisoning

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is given Intravenously:

  • This is a case of organophosphate poisoning.
  • Pralidoxime is an oxime which is given intravenously.
  • 30 mg/kg i.v. loading dose, followed by 8- 10 mg/kg/hour continuous infusion till recovery
  • Oximes are given for the reactivation of the inhibited acetylcholinesterase in organophosphate poisoning.
  • Two oximes are used :
    • PAM (Pralidoxime): does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
    • DAM (Diacetyl mono-oxime): crosses the blood-brain border, both central and peripheral action.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It should be started after 24 hours of poisoning:

  • Oximes (pralidoxime and diacetyl mono-oxime ) should be started as soon as possible after atropine is given.
  • If taken a long time, then enzyme ageing may occur (enzyme cannot work)

Option C - It crosses the blood-brain barrier:

  • Pralidoxime cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • There is another oxime called diacetyl mono-oxime; it can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Option D - Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme:

  • Pralidoxime is given for the reactivation of the inhibited acetylcholinesterase in organophosphate poisoning.
  • Organophosphate inhibits the acetylcholinesterase enzyme

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is a known case of epilepsy. She has been prescribed phenytoin to control her seizures. After getting into a fight with her husband, she takes the whole bottle of pills. High plasma drug concentrations of phenytoin can cause which of the following toxic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Ataxia:

  • Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.
  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.
  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.
  • Cerebellar dysfunction, i.e., ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo, diplopia, and sedation, are seen at toxic plasma concentrations.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gum hyperplasia:

  • The major side effects of phenytoin that occurs at therapeutic doses with prolonged use include;
    • Gingival hyperplasia
    • Hirsutism
    • Pseudolymphoma
    • Fetal hydantoin syndrome
    • Cytochrome P-450 induction
    • Yellow-brown discolouration of the skin
    • Osteopenia
    • Inhibited folate absorption
    • Neuropathy

Option C - Steven-Johnson syndrome:

  • Steven-Johnson syndrome, DRESS syndrome, and drug-induced lupus occur at therapeutic doses of phenytoin but with prolonged use but occur very rarely.
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome is commonly caused as a side effect of lamotrigine.

Option D - All of the above:

  • Although all of the mentioned options are side effects of phenytoin, only cerebellar dysfunction occurs due to phenytoin toxicity. All others occur at therapeutic doses but with prolonged use

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of erectile dysfunction is prescribed a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitor. Which of the following statements regarding PDE-5 inhibitors is correct?

choices.text: PDE-5 inhibitors act primarily by increasing testosterone levels.
These inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to the risk of severe hypotension.
The main mechanism of action of PDE-5 inhibitors is prolong the effects of cGMP.
PDE-5 inhibitors should be taken concurrently with nitrate medications for optimal efficacy.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The main mechanism of action of PDE-5 inhibitors is prolong the effects of cGMP:

  • PDE-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), and vardenafil (Levitra), work by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5, an enzyme that degrades cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). By inhibiting PDE-5, these medications enhance the vasodilatory effects of cGMP, leading to increased blood flow to the erectile tissues of the penis, ultimately aiding in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - PDE-5 inhibitors act primarily by increasing testosterone levels:

  • PDE-5 inhibitors do not directly impact testosterone levels. Their primary mechanism involves the nitric oxide pathway and the regulation of cGMP, leading to vasodilation and improved blood flow, which are essential for achieving and maintaining an erection.

Option B - These inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to the risk of severe hypotension:

  • While caution is advised in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, PDE-5 inhibitors are not an absolute contraindication. They may be used with careful monitoring in such patients. The risk of hypotension is more significant when these medications are taken concomitantly with nitrates.

Option D - PDE-5 inhibitors should be taken concurrently with nitrate medications for optimal efficacy:

  • Concurrent use of PDE-5 inhibitors with nitrates is contraindicated due to the risk of severe hypotension. Combining these medications can lead to a dangerous drop in blood pressure and is to be avoided.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with hypertension is initiated on a new antihypertensive medication. The dose-response curve for this drug is being evaluated. Which of the following statements regarding the dose-response curve is correct?

choices.text: The steepness of the curve indicates a narrow therapeutic window, requiring careful titration.
A shift to the left on the dose-response curve suggests decreased potency to the drug.
The ED50 (effective dose for 50% of the maximal response) represents the maximum efficacy of the drug.
A plateau phase on the dose-response curve suggests that further dose escalation may lead to increased risk of adverse effects without proportional therapeutic benefits.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The steepness of the curve indicates a narrow therapeutic window, requiring careful titration:

  • A steep dose-response curve implies that small changes in dose lead to significant changes in response. In the context of medications, this suggests a narrow therapeutic window, meaning that there is a small range between the minimum effective dose and the minimum toxic dose. Careful titration is necessary to avoid adverse effects while achieving therapeutic benefits.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - A shift to the left on the dose-response curve suggests decreased potency to the drug:

  • A shift to the left on the dose-response curve indicates increased sensitivity or potency to the drug. It means that a lower dose is needed to produce the same effect, indicating heightened responsiveness rather than decreased sensitivity.

Option C - The ED50 represents the maximum efficacy of the drug:

  • The ED50 (effective dose for 50% of the maximal response) is the dose at which 50% of the maximal response is achieved, but it does not represent the maximum efficacy of the drug. Maximal efficacy is typically represented at the upper plateau of the dose-response curve.

Option D - A plateau phase on the dose-response curve suggests that further dose escalation may lead to increased risk of adverse effects without proportional therapeutic benefits:

  • A plateau phase on the dose-response curve indicates that the maximum therapeutic effect has been reached, but it doesn't necessarily suggest an increased risk of adverse effects with further dose escalation. Adverse effects may or may not increase with higher doses, and the decision to escalate the dose should consider the balance between therapeutic benefits and potential side effects.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure is prescribed a diuretic as part of her management. Which of the following statements regarding diuretics is correct?

choices.text: Diuretics increase the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), promoting water retention.
Diuretics primarily act on the renal tubules to decrease the reabsorption of sodium and water.
Loop diuretics are commonly associated with hyperkalemia as a side effect.
Thiazide diuretics are the first-line treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diuretics primarily act on the renal tubules to decrease the reabsorption of sodium and water:

  • Diuretics primarily act on the renal tubules to decrease the reabsorption of sodium and water. This is achieved by various classes of diuretics, such as thiazides, loop diuretics, and potassium-sparing diuretics. By inhibiting or blocking specific transporters and channels in the nephron, diuretics enhance the excretion of sodium and water, reducing blood volume and subsequently lowering blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diuretics increase the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), promoting water retention:

  • Diuretics have the opposite effect; they increase urine production by promoting the excretion of water and electrolytes. They do not stimulate the release of antidiuretic hormone, which would enhance water reabsorption.

Option C - Loop diuretics are commonly associated with hyperkalemia as a side effect:

  • Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, are more commonly associated with hypokalemia as they increase the excretion of both sodium and potassium. Hyperkalemia is a potential side effect of potassium-sparing diuretics.

Option D - Thiazide diuretics are the first-line treatment for acute pulmonary edema:

  • Thiazide diuretics are not typically used as first-line treatment for acute pulmonary edema. Loop diuretics, like furosemide, are preferred in this situation due to their rapid onset and potent diuretic effect in the loop of Henle. Thiazides are often used for managing hypertension and mild heart failure.

questions.text: Sarah, a 9-year-old girl, is brought to a developmental clinic by her parents. Her parents say she doesn't like to interact with others in school as well as in society. Sarah has good language skills and has never experienced any language delay. She struggles with non-verbal communicative gestures and often engages in repetitive behaviours. Her parents are concerned about her condition and seek a diagnosis. Based on the presented scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis for Sarah?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Asperger syndrome:

  • This is the most likely diagnosis for Sarah based on the presented scenario. Asperger syndrome is characterized by good language skills without any language delay, impairment in non-verbal communicative gestures, and a repetitive pattern of behaviour. Sarah's struggle with non-verbal gestures and engaging in repetitive behaviours aligns with the symptoms of Asperger syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intellectual Disability Disorder:

  • Intellectual disability, formerly known as mental retardation, is a condition characterized by limitations in cognitive functioning and adaptive behaviour. It typically manifests during childhood and results in difficulties with learning, problem-solving, and independent daily living.

Option C - Specific Language Impairment (SLI):

  • SLI is characterized by difficulties specifically in language acquisition and use, but Sarah's good language skills indicate that language impairment is not the primary concern.

Option D - Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD):

  • ADHD involves symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are not specifically mentioned in the scenario. Sarah's difficulties primarily revolve around social interactions and repetitive behaviours, suggesting a different diagnosis.

questions.text: During a routine psychiatric evaluation, a 30-year-old male patient is observed to display unusual motor symptoms. The examiner attempts to move his arms, but there is a noticeable resistance initially and then the examiner can move the arms freely and makes the patient come in a position as shown in the image below and slowly the arms of the patient come down. Which of the following terms best describes the patient’s behaviour?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Waxy flexibility:

  • Waxy flexibility is a motor symptom commonly observed in patients with catatonic features of schizophrenia. It is characterized by the feeling of resistance encountered when attempting to move the patient's limbs or body into different positions. The patient's body seems to exhibit a pliable and moldable quality, similar to the bending of a wax candle. Waxy flexibility is a passive phenomenon, meaning the resistance is felt when the examiner tries to move the patient's body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Catalepsy:

  • Catalepsy refers to maintaining an odd posture for an extended period. It is a passive phenomenon where the patient maintains the posture in response to external instructions, such as the examiner asking the patient to hold a particular position. Catalepsy does not involve the feeling of resistance encountered during movement, as seen in the described scenario.

Option B – Posturing:

  • Posturing is similar to catalepsy in that it involves maintaining an odd posture for an extended duration. However, posturing is an active phenomenon where the patient spontaneously assumes the posture without external instructions. In the described scenario, the patient complies with the examiner's request, suggesting a response to external instruction rather than spontaneous posturing.

Option D – Negativism:

  • Negativism refers to the patient's opposition or lack of response to instructions. It is characterized by a resistance to comply with commands or a tendency to do the opposite of what is requested. While negativism can be observed in patients with catatonic features, it does not specifically describe the motor symptoms mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text: A 21-year-old individual presents to the emergency department after attending a party. On examination, the person appears euphoric, with redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, impaired motor coordination, and is talking continuously. The person also experiences a sense of time distortion and complains of dry mouth. The most likely diagnosis for this individual is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cannabis Intoxication:

  • This option is the correct answer as the individual presents with the typical symptoms of cannabis intoxication, including euphoria, redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, impaired motor coordination, sense of time distortion, and dry mouth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Alcohol Intoxication:

  • While alcohol intoxication can cause euphoria and impaired motor coordination, it typically does not cause redness of the conjunctiva or increased appetite. Dry mouth can be seen with alcohol intoxication but is more commonly associated with cannabis use.

Option C - Cocaine Intoxication:

  • Cocaine intoxication can cause euphoria, increased energy, and impaired motor coordination. However, it does not typically cause redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, or a sense of time distortion.

Option D - Amphetamine Intoxication:

  • Amphetamine intoxication can lead to euphoria, increased energy, and impaired motor coordination. However, it does not typically cause redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, or a sense of time distortion. Additionally, dry mouth is more commonly associated with cannabis use.

questions.text: At what BAC level is an individual likely to experience incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 80-200 mg/dl:

  • Incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability are associated with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level of 80-200 mg/dl.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 20-30 mg/dl:

  • Slowed motor performance is seen at BAC levels of 20-30 mg/dl and not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

Option B - 30-80 mg/dl:

  • An increase in cognitive problems are seen at BAC levels of 30-80 mg/dl, not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

Option D - 200-300 mg/dl:

  • Nystagmus, slurring speech, and alcoholic blackouts are seen at BAC levels of 200-300 mg/dl, not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female tourist who had been missing for a week was found near a waterfall, the forensic team has noted the presence of Masque Ecchymotique. What could this finding suggest as a possible cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Traumatic asphyxia:

  • The presence of Masque Ecchymotique, indicates traumatic asphyxia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ligature strangulation:

  • The ligature mark is transverse, complete below the thyroid cartilage (mostly).
  • Masque Ecchymotique is not seen in this case.

Option B - Manual strangulation:

  • Constriction of the neck by hands/ fingers manually is known as manual strangulation.
  • Masque Ecchymotique is not seen in this case.

Option D - Drowning:

  • Drowning involves submersion in a liquid, usually water, leading to respiratory failure. While drowning can cause external signs of trauma, it doesn't typically result in Masque Ecchymotique.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of recurrent aggressive fantasies, a fascination with causing physical or psychological suffering to others, and a notable lack of empathy. The patient describes deriving pleasure from inflicting pain and humiliation. What psychiatric term is most appropriate to describe this pattern of behavior?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sadism:

  • Sexual preference disorder focuses on the infliction of suffering, pain, or humiliation to achieve sexual gratification.
  • To obtain sexual gratification the sadist may hurt or ill-treat or torture his sexual partner in many other cruel ways.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Voyeurism:

  • Voyeurism is the act of observing or spying on individuals who are naked or engaged in sexual activity without their knowledge or consent, for the purpose of sexual gratification. This behavior does not involve inflicting pain or harm on others, as in the scenario described.

Option B - Fetishism:

  • Fetishism is a type of sexual disorder in which an individual is sexually aroused by inanimate objects (bra and underpants) of the opposite sex.

Option D - Masochism:

  • Masochism is a sexual disorder in which an individual derives sexual pleasure from receiving pain or humiliation. In the scenario described, the individual is inflicting pain and harm on their partner rather than receiving it themselves.

questions.text: Which IPC section is applicable in cases involving criminal abortion without the woman's consent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IPC 313:

  • Section 313 of the IPC states the punishment for conducting criminal abortion without the consent of a female

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IPC 312:

  • Punishment for conducting criminal abortion with the consent of the pregnant female

Option C - IPC 314:

  • Punishment for any kind of criminal abortion resulting in the death of the female.

Option D - IPC 315:

  • Gives punishment for any person who does an act, with the intent to prevent the child from being born alive to cause it to die after birth.

questions.text: Who conducts the inquest when a male, who kidnapped a 14-year-old girl, is arrested by the police but dies while in police custody?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Judicial magistrate:

  • The inquest in the given scenario would typically be conducted by a Judicial magistrate.
  • Judicial magistrate conducts the inquest for police beating deaths as well as police custodial deaths.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Police:

  • The police are responsible for inquest in cases of unnatural deaths like in :
    • Accidental case
    • Suicide case
    • Homicide case

Option B - Executive magistrate:

  • The executive magistrate can con conduct an inquest in the following cases:
    • Dowry death
    • Exhumation
    • Encounter death

Option C - Medical examiner:

  • A Medical Examiner may provide valuable information and evidence during an inquest, but they are not typically responsible for conducting the inquest itself.

questions.text: Among the listed ethnic groups, which one is typically associated with the brachycephalic index type?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mongol:

  • Individuals with a cephalic index in the range of 80-84.9 are classified as Brachycephalic, and this index type is associated with the Mongol ethnic group.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Negros:

  • Negros, or individuals of African descent, are associated with the Dolicocephalic cephalic index type (70-74.9). This means that the length of their skulls is longer relative to the width.

Option B - Indians:

  • Indians are associated with the Mesaticephalic cephalic index type (75-79.9). Mesaticephalic individuals have a skull shape that falls between dolichocephalic and brachycephalic, with a moderate length-to-width ratio.

Option C - Chinese:

  • Chinese individuals are also associated with the Mesaticephalic cephalic index type (75-79.9), similar to Indians. The term "M-ICE" is a mnemonic to remember Mesaticephalic, and it includes Indians, Chinese, and Europeans.

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Atropa Belladonna:

  • The above image shows Atropa Belladonna, also called the deadly nightshade. It produces an active poisonous component called hyoscyamine.
  • It has antimuscarinic properties and can cause toxicity when ingested.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Datura Alba:

  • Active Principle:
    • Hyoscine (Most important) aka Scopolamine
    • Hyoscyamine
    • Atropine [trace amounts]
  • It has Anticholinergic properties

Option B - Ricinus communis:

  • Active Principle:
    • Ricin
    • Ricinoleic acid
  • Mechanism of Action
    • Ricin is RIP i.e Ribosomal Inactivating Protein
    • It inhibits protein synthesis, resulting in cell death, necrosis & inflammation

 

Option C - Digitalis Purpurea:

  • Active Principle:
    • Digitoxin, Digoxin
  • Mechanism of toxicity:
    • Inhibits Na - K ATPase pump resulting in electrolyte abnormalities & cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: In the postmortem examination of a 42-year-old man who was HIV positive and has passed away, what is the optimal technique for extracting organs during the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rokitansky method:

  • Rokitansky's technique: It involves in situ dissection in part, combined with en block removal.
  • It is the preferred choice in patients with highly transmissible diseases, such as HIV, and hepatitis B.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Letulle’s method:

  • Lettulle's technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed en masse and dissected as organ blocks.
  • It has the advantage of leaving all attachments intact.

Option B - Ghon’s method:

  • Ghon's Technique: Cervical, thoracic, abdominal organs and urogenital system are removed as organ blocks.
  • The neuronal system is removed as another block.

Option D - Virchow method:

  • Virchow's technique: Individual organs are removed one by one.
  • The cranial cavity is exposed first, followed by the thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs. The spinal cord is removed from the back.
  • In this, the anatomical-pathologic relations are not preserved.

questions.text: What type of poisoning is most likely responsible for the clinical presentation of a patient with a history of glassblowing, exhibiting symptoms such as ataxia, tremors, speech disturbances, vision/hearing disturbances, and numbness in the fingers and toes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mercury poisoning:

  • Mercury poisoning can manifest in various forms, including Minamata disease. Neurological symptoms like ataxia, tremors, speech disturbances, and sensory disturbances are characteristic. Exposure can occur through inhalation, ingestion, or skin contact with certain forms of mercury.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Lead poisoning:

  • Lead poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as abdominal pain, constipation, fatigue, irritability, and cognitive deficits. Neurological symptoms may include headaches and, in severe cases, seizures.
  • It can manifest as Burtonian lines, Saturine gout

Option B - Phosphorus:

  • Phosphorus poisoning can occur in industrial settings, often through ingestion. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Severe cases can lead to liver damage and multi-organ failure.
  • It can manifest as Smoky stool syndrome

Option D - Arsenic poisoning:

  • Arsenic poisoning can result from exposure to inorganic arsenic compounds. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and in severe cases, multi-organ failure. Chronic exposure can lead to skin changes and an increased risk of certain cancers.
  • It can manifest as Raindrop pigmentation, Black foot disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia plan involves the use of halothane. The anesthesiologist is considering the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) of halothane. What does a higher MAC value for halothane indicate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Decreased anesthetic potency:

  • The Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) represents the concentration of an inhalational anesthetic at which 50% of patients do not respond to a surgical stimulus. A higher MAC value indicates decreased potency, meaning a higher concentration of the anesthetic is needed to achieve the desired effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased anesthetic potency:

  • A higher MAC value indicates decreased potency, not increased potency. A lower MAC value reflects greater potency, as less anesthetic is needed to produce the desired effect.

Option B - Faster onset of action:

  • MAC is not directly related to the onset of action. The onset of action is influenced by factors such as blood solubility and alveolar ventilation, whereas MAC specifically refers to the concentration needed for a lack of response to a surgical stimulus.

Option C - Lower concentration required for anesthesia:

  • A higher MAC value indicates that a higher concentration of the anesthetic is required for anesthesia, not a lower concentration. Lower MAC values represent greater potency.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is considered the most reliable for confirming the correct placement of an endotracheal tube in a 30-year-old male patient who has been intubated for surgery by the final-year resident?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- End-tidal CO2 concentration:

  • End-tidal CO2 concentration is the ideal method to confirm the endotracheal tube position during surgery.
  • This technique is also known as capnography. This technique measures the amount of CO2 in the exhaled breath.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Chest X-ray:

  • Chest X-ray takes time, and the process can introduce a delay between intubation and confirmation. During this time, critical issues such as hypoxia due to esophageal intubation may go unnoticed.
  • In critical situations, immediate confirmation of endotracheal tube placement is crucial for patient safety. Waiting for a chest X-ray may not be feasible in such cases.

Option B- Auscultation:

  • Auscultation can be used to identify the initial clues of the endotracheal tube placement.
  • However, it cannot be used as a definitive technique as the breath sounds can be misleading and produce false results.

Option C- Pulse oximetry:

  • Pulse oximetry provides information about oxygen saturation but does not confirm the endotracheal tube's location. In cases of esophageal intubation, oxygen saturation can still be maintained, leading to a false sense of security. EtCO2 is a more direct indicator of correct tube placement.

questions.text: What is the colour of the nitrous oxide cylinder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Blue:

  • In the standardized colour-coding system for gas cylinders, blue is the designated colour for nitrous oxide.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- White shoulder and Black body:

  • Oxygen cylinder has white shoulder and black body

Option C- Brown:

  • Heliox cylinder has Brown colour code

Option D- Grey:

  • Carbon dioxide has Grey colour code

questions.text: What are the potential complications associated with the administration of spinal anesthesia into the subarachnoid space?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Post Dural puncture headache:

  • Postdural puncture headache (PDPH) is a potential complication resulting from dura cutting and thicker needles during spinal anesthesia. Leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the puncture site can lead to headaches, especially in the upright position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Hypertension: Hypertension is not a typical complication of spinal anesthesia into the subarachnoid space.

Option B- Epidural hematoma: Epidural hematoma is not a direct consequence of spinal anesthesia entering the subarachnoid space. It is more commonly associated with bleeding into the epidural space.

Option C- Subdural block: Subdural block is not a recognized complication of the spinal anesthesia into the subarachnoid space. It is important to ensure the accurate placement of the needle during spinal anesthesia to avoid complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the hospital with a history of radiation exposure due to previous radiotherapy for a childhood malignancy. On examination, a suspicious thyroid nodule is identified. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy confirms the presence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most common type of thyroid cancer associated with the patient's history of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Papillary carcinoma:

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the most common type of thyroid cancer associated with radiation exposure. It is characterized by papillary growth patterns and nuclear features such as nuclear grooves and intranuclear pseudo-inclusions. Previous radiation exposure, especially during childhood, significantly increases the risk of developing papillary carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Follicular carcinoma: Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is typically not associated with radiation exposure.

Option B - Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid arises from the parafollicular C-cells and is commonly associated with genetic mutations, particularly RET proto-oncogene mutations. Radiation exposure is not a known risk factor for medullary carcinoma.

Option D - Anaplastic carcinoma: Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is an aggressive and rare form of thyroid cancer. It is not typically associated with radiation exposure. Anaplastic carcinoma tends to occur in older individuals and has a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male was brought to the ER in a state of unresponsiveness. He was intubated immediately and an x-ray was done. Which condition is most commonly associated with the findings given in the radiograph below?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Renal cell carcinoma:

  • The given chest X-ray reveals a "cannonball" appearance, characterized by multiple round nodules scattered throughout the lung fields, and is often associated with metastases. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is known for its ability to metastasize to the lungs. These metastatic nodules can present as multiple, well-defined round lesions, creating a cannonball appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Miliary TB:

  • Miliary TB is characterized by tiny, millet-sized nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It presents as a diffuse pattern of small nodules rather than the larger, round lesions resembling cannonballs. The appearance is different from the described findings in the chest X-ray.

Option B - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma:

  • Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. While breast cancer can metastasize to the lungs, the pattern of metastasis is often diverse and may not consistently present as a cannonball appearance.

Option D - Small Cell Carcinoma of the Lungs:

  • Small cell carcinoma of the lungs is a highly aggressive type of lung cancer. While lung cancers can metastasize, the cannonball appearance is not particularly characteristic of small cell carcinoma. This pattern is more commonly associated with metastases from other primary tumors.

Match the following X-rays with their characteristic features:
