questions.text:
A 60-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a persistent cough and fever. Chest CT reveals the following:



What is the most likely organism responsible for the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • The "tree-in-bud" appearance on chest CT is a characteristic finding associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections. This appearance represents centrilobular nodules and branching linear opacities, indicating the spread of infection along the airways and bronchioles. In immunocompromised individuals, such as the presented patient, tuberculosis can manifest with atypical radiological patterns.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2):

  • COVID-19 typically presents with bilateral, peripheral ground-glass opacities on chest CT. The "tree-in-bud" appearance is not a typical radiological finding in COVID-19 pneumonia.

Option C - Aspergillus:

  • Aspergillus infections can lead to various radiological patterns, including nodules and cavities, but the "tree-in-bud" appearance is more characteristic of mycobacterial infections like tuberculosis.

Option D - Klebsiella:

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause pneumonia with a tendency for cavitary lesions. However, the "tree-in-bud" appearance is not typically associated with Klebsiella pneumonia.

questions.text: A middle-aged female with sudden onset of headache and neck rigidity. There is no history of trauma. NCCT head scan is shown below. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):

  • The sudden onset of headache and neck rigidity, especially without a history of trauma, is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The NCCT scan image showing star of death appearance further supports this diagnosis. SAH refers to bleeding into the space between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater, usually caused by the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm. The most common symptom is a severe headache, often described as "the worst headache of my life."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Meningitis:

  • While meningitis can present with headache and neck rigidity, the acute onset and the presence of star of death appearance on NCCT scan make SAH a more likely diagnosis in this case.

Option C - Epidural Hematoma:

  • Epidural hematomas typically result from trauma, and they are characterized by bleeding between the skull and the dura mater. The absence of trauma makes this an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D - Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH):

  • Intraventricular hemorrhage involves bleeding into the brain's ventricular system. While it can occur, especially in premature infants, the symptoms described are more indicative of SAH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, revealing dilatation of the esophagus with a narrowed distal esophageal segment, and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achalasia cardia:

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter and absent peristalsis in the oesophagus. The classic radiographic finding in achalasia is the "bird's beak" appearance, which represents the narrowed and tapered distal oesophagus on a barium swallow study.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):

  • GERD refers to the backward flow of gastric contents into the oesophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn and regurgitation. It does not typically present with the "bird's beak" appearance seen in achalasia.

Option C - Oesophageal carcinoma:

  • Oesophageal carcinoma refers to malignant tumours arising from the oesophageal epithelium. While it can cause oesophageal narrowing, apple core appearance is seen.

Option D - Oesophageal web:

  • Oesophageal webs are seen in Plummer Vinson syndrome. A smooth, thin strip may be seen on X-ray in case of esophageal web.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy underwent knee surgery for a ligament tear. A vertical incision was made. As a result, the wound edges kept gaping, and poor healing was observed. Which concept of skin anatomy explains the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Langer's lines:

  • Langer's lines, also known as cleavage lines or tension lines, represent the natural orientation of collagen fibers within the skin. These lines indicate the direction of tension and elasticity in the skin. When surgical incisions are made parallel to Langer's lines, the wound edges align with the natural tension lines, resulting in better wound healing and minimal scarring. However, in this case, the incision was made perpendicular to the lines of tension, leading to a tendency for the wound edges to gape and heal poorly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blaschko lines: Blaschko lines represent an invisible pattern of embryonic cell migration and are not directly related to wound healing or surgical incisions. They are important in understanding certain skin conditions that follow this pattern of distribution, but they do not explain the phenomenon described in the question.

Option B - Terry’s lines: These refer to lines in the nails - the nail is white proximally and normal distally. These are not associated with the skin concept asked in the question.

Option D - Mees lines: These are transverse white lines that traverse fingernails. They are commonly seen in arsenic poisoning. These are not associated with the skin concept asked in the question.

questions.text: Which of the following phenomenon is most likely to be seen in a patient of verruca vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pseudo Koebner phenomenon:

  • Pseudokoebner phenomenon refers to the development of new skin lesions along the lines of trauma caused to an existing skin lesion, thereby causing it to spread to those sites.
  • Therefore, it is practically autoinoculation of the new sites.
  • It is seen in infections- warts, molluscum

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lucio phenomenon: Lucio’s phenomenon is an uncommon and unusual reaction that occurs in patients with diffuse lepromatous leprosy (DLL). It is not seen in verruca vulgaris.

Option B - Koebner phenomenon: The Koebner phenomenon, also known as the isomorphic response, refers to the development of new skin lesions or the worsening of pre-existing lesions at sites of skin trauma. It is commonly observed in individuals with psoriasis, LP and vitiligo but the history of these pathologies is not described in the question ruling out this option.

Option D - Uhthoff phenomenon: It refers to a phenomenon of neurological symptoms that are triggered by heat exposure. It is not associated with verruca vulgaris. It is seen in Multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who has recently moved here from Iran came with complaints of progressively enlarging vesicles on her back. She gives a similar history of the appearance of vesicles attributing it to mental stress. On examination, a few vesicles and bullae are seen that are bulla spread sign positive. A biopsy shows intra-epidermal involvement of the blister. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an immuno-bullous disorder characterized by intraepidermal blister formation. It is caused by autoantibodies targeting desmoglein proteins, which are components of the desmosomal adhesion complexes that hold keratinocytes together in the epidermis. The autoantibodies disrupt the adhesion between keratinocytes, leading to the formation of blisters within the epidermis. The positive bulla spread sign is a characteristic feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bullous pemphigoid: Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by sub-epidermal blister formation, rather than intraepidermal blister formation. It is caused by autoantibodies targeting components of the basement membrane zone, specifically BP180 and BP230.

Option C - Epidermolysis bullosa: Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of acquired disorders characterized by blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. Bullae are formed at the site of trauma and they heal with scarring.

Option D - Dermatitis herpetiformis: Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune disorder. Itchy excoriated papulo-vesicular lesions are present on extensors and trunk. No bulla are seen.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female came with peculiar complaints about her fingernails. The image depicts the cause for her concern.



Which of the following statements is true regarding this presentation?

choices.text: It is caused due to hypoalbuminemia
It can be blanched and is caused by external factors.
It results from a localized problem in the nail matrix.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – It results from a localized problem in the nail matrix:

  • The image suggests diagnosis of true leukonychia. True leukonychia refers to the presence of white discoloration in the nail plate. It is caused by a localized problem in the nail matrix, which is the area where the nail is formed. This can result from trauma, injury, or inflammation of the nail matrix or in case of arsenic, thallium poisoning and chemotherapy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - It is caused due to hypoalbuminemia:

  • True leukonychia is not caused due to hypoalbuminemia. Hypoalbuminemia causes false leukonychia that are called Muehrcke's paired white bands.

Option B - It can be blanched and is caused by external factors:

  • True leukonychia is caused by a localized problem in the nail matrix and the spots cannot be blanched. Blanching may be present in cases of false leukonychia.

Option D - It is a contagious condition that can spread from person to person:

  • True leukonychia is not a contagious condition that can spread from person to person.

questions.text: In a syphilitic patient who has progressed into the secondary stage of the disease, one is most likely to observe which of the following signs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Buschke Ollendorff sign:

  • The presence of hyperpigmented plaques on the palms and soles is characteristic of the Buschke Ollendorff sign, which is a clinical finding often seen in secondary syphilis. They cause pain when pressed by a blunt pin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nikolsky sign:

  • In diseases like pemphigus vulgaris and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), the Nikolsky sign is positive, leading to the detachment of the epidermis with slight pressure. However, this sign is not associated with the second stage of syphilis.

Option B - Koebner phenomenon:

  • The Koebner phenomenon, also known as the isomorphic response, is a skin reaction that refers to the appearance of new lesions or eruptions in areas of previously normal skin following trauma or injury. It is not linked to secondary syphilis.

Option C - Darier's sign:

  • Darier's sign- When you stroke with a pen or key- erythematous wheals are seen. It is seen in urticaria pigmentosa.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent attacks of vertigo for 7 months associated with hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the left ear. An audiogram is done as shown below. Which of the following will be seen as an examination finding in this patient?



                                       x : AC, ]:BC
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low-frequency SNHL:

  • The other test performed in patients with Meniere's disease is an audiogram where it is typically observed that the hearing loss is more at lower frequencies.
  • Thus, at 250 hertz, the hearing threshold is at 70.
  • X is for air conduction of your left ear and close bracket - ']' is for bone conduction of your left ear.
  • Both air conduction and bone conduction are aﬀected because it's a sensorineural pathology.
  • At lower frequencies, the hearing loss is higher whereas at higher frequencies, the hearing is better. The graph is of an upsloping type of audiogram for left ear.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Webers towards the affected ear:

  • Rinne will be positive towards the normal ear, whereas Weber will be towards the affected ear.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C - SP/AP < 30%:

  • Testing the electrical activity produced by the eighth nerve and cochlea is known as electrocochleography and it is investigation of choice to diagnose meniere disease. SP/AP < 30% is suggestive of meniere disease. It can be used for intraoperative cochlear and eighth nerve monitoring.
  • The summating potential to action potential ratio i.e., SP/AP < 30% or 0.3 in normal individuals.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of an increase in the size of his nose over the past few years. He is a diabetic with a history of chronic smoking for the past 20 years. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Co2 laser debridement:

  • Rhinophyma is hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of patients with acne rosacea or diabetes mellitus or in elderly patients.
  • TOC is the removal of the tissue by carbon dioxide laser debridement of the hypertrophic tissue with a skin graft.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Augmentation rhinoplasty: Augmentation rhinoplasty is usually done in case of saddle nose deformity. It does not have any role in treating Rhinophyma

Option B - Surgical excision: Surgical excision with radiation is not a treatment choice for rhinophyma. It is used as a choice of treatment in squamous cell carcinoma

Option D - Reduction Rhinoplasty: Reduction Rhinoplasty is made to remove the excess bone edge in case of hump nose deformity

questions.text: Merciful anosmia is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atrophic rhinitis:

  • Merciful anosmia: Patient himself is unware of the smell due to marked anosmia.
  • The patient may complain of nasal obstruction inspite of unduly wide nasal chambers
  • It is a feature of Atrophic rhinitis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Drug-induced rhinitis:

  • If the drug as a side effect is causing rhinitis, then it is called drug-induced rhinitis.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature

Option C - Vasomotor rhinitis:

  • When the symptoms are similar to allergy but serum IgE is normal, eosinophil count is normal called Vasomotor rhinitis.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature

Option D - Non allergic rhinitis:

  • It is defined as allergic rhinitis but clinically stimulates nasal allergy with symptoms of nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea, and sneezing but the serum IgE level is normal.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature of Non-allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent epistaxis. Holmann miller sign is seen on CT scan. Which of the following is the most common site of origin for the condition that the patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sphenopalatine foramen:

  • Angiofibroma is a tumor filled with lots of blood vessels andfibrous tissue.
  • Most common site of origin is from sphenopalatine foramen (near posterior wall of maxillary sinus).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fossa of rosenmuller:

  • JNA does not originate form fossa of rosenmuller
  • It is a site of origin for Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Option C - Maxillary sinus:

  • JNA does not originate from maxillary sinus

Option D - Pituitary:

  • JNA does not originate from pituitary
  • Pituitary adenoma is a benign tumour that arises in pituitary

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his mother to the clinic with complaints of inattention and poor school performance. He had a history of fever and otalgia 12 weeks ago. A tympanometry was done. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 

  • SOM is a common sequel to Acute otitis media in children and may persist for weeks to months when the air reaching the Eustachian tube or the ventilation to the middle ear gets reduced.
  • This results in negative pressure in the middle ear.
  • If this negative pressure is present for some time, it acts on the mucosal cells of the middle ear.
  • Slowly there's exudate formation in the middle ear.
  • Presence of air bubbles and air-fluid level (hallmark for SOM).
  • Type B represents a flat curve seen if there is fluid in the middle ear

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 

  • Type A represents a normal tympanogram

 

Option C - 

  • Type C is seen in eustachian tube obstruction
  • Represents maximum compliance in negative pressure

 

Option D - 

  • Type Ad is seen in diseases such as otosclerosis.
  • It represents lower compliance at or near ambient pressure

questions.text: A 28-year-old male underwent endoscopic sinus surgery. later on, the patient developed periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision. Which of the following has caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ethmoidal artery bleed:

  • Blurring of vision is mostly caused by the traumatized ethmoidal artery. As they are traveling from the medial wall of the orbit to the ethmoidal sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sphenopalatine bleeding:

  • The sphenopalatine artery is also known as the artery of epistaxis but in this case, the periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision is caused by the trauma to the ethmoidal artery

Option C - IMA bleed:

  • Internal maxillary artery can be traumatized intraoperatively during Posterior osteotomy
  • Not in the case of endoscopic sinus surgery

Option D - Facial artery bleed:

  • The facial artery gives rise to a superior labial artery. The superior labial artery supplies the septum inferiorly via the septal branch. however, periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision are caused by trauma to the ethmoidal artery

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a tall stature and elongated limbs. On examination, he demonstrates hypermobility of the joints and has a family history of similar features. The ophthalmologist is consulted to evaluate for ocular manifestations. What is the most common ocular feature associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Superio-temporal ectopia lentis:

  • The clinical picture of tall stature, elongated limbs, hypermobility of the joints, and family history of similar features gives the diagnosis of Marfan’s Syndrome.

  • The most common ocular feature associated with Marfan syndrome is ectopia lentis, the lens typically dislocates in a superio-temporal direction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Megalocornea: Megalocornea refers to an abnormally large cornea. This is the most prominent ocular feature seen in patients suffering from Marfan's Syndrome.

Option B - Inferio-nasal ectopia lentis: Inferio-nasal ectopia lentis is seen in patients with homocystinuria.

Option D – Retinal detachment: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is seen in patients suffering from Marfan's Syndrome but the most common feature of Marfan's Syndrome is Superio-temporal ectopia lentis. Patient with Stickler syndrome presents with retinal detachment as the most common ocular feature.

questions.text:
Match the following images with their accurate description


	
		
			
			1. 

			
			
			
			a. Dendritic ulcer
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Superficial punctate keratitis
			
		
		
			
			3. 

			 
			
			
			c. Pseudo dendritis
			
		
		
			
			4. 
			
			
			d. Nummular keratitis
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a:

  • This option correctly matches all the images with their correct description.

Image 1 - Superficial punctate keratitis: Superficial punctate keratitis (SPK) is a condition characterized by multiple, fine, pinpoint epithelial erosions on the surface of the cornea often seen as punctate or dot-like lesions on the corneal surface caused from viral infections like Herpes simplex virus.

Image 2 – Pseudo dendritis: Pseudo dendritis is seen in viral keratitis caused by Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus. It has no knob ends as seen in dendritic ulcer caused due to herpes simplex virus.

Image 3 – Nummular keratitis: It is seen in case of stromal involvement by Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus. Seen as a coin shape just under the epithelium.

Image 4 - Dendritic ulcer: There are knob ends filled with viruses as seen in the image, they are usually linear. It is caused by herpes simplex virus.

 

All Other options A, B, and D incorrectly match the image with their description.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a known history of multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of granulomas most commonly involving lungs presents with floaters and vision loss in his right eye. On examination, you observe segmented venous sheathing on the fundus examination. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Candle wax dripping:

  • The systemic disease in question is referred to as Sarcoidosis and the segmented venous sheathing seen in patients suffering from sarcoidosis is called Candle wax dripping.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lander’s sign: It is a pre-retinal nodule (exact location - Posterior hyaloid membrane of vitreous and retina) seen in patients suffering from Sarcoidosis.

Option B – Iris pearls: Iris pearls are pathognomonic feature of leprosy associated with Uveitis, mainly containing bacteria.

Option C – Suguira’s sign: Perilimbal depigmentation is called Suiguira’s sign seen in the Convalescent phase of Vogt Koyanagi Harada Syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with diabetes presents with a painful, red eye and decreased vision. On examination, a perforating corneal ulcer with stromal edema is observed. The patient has developed these symptoms in the past 48 hours. Which organism is commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is known for causing rapidly progressing and potentially severe corneal infections. The quick onset of symptoms (usually presents with corneal perforation within 48 hours), along with the presence of stromal edema, is consistent with bacterial keratitis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common culprit in such cases. Pseudomonas release exotoxins which have collagenolytic effect causing perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is not a common cause of rapidly progressing corneal ulcers. While it can be associated with ocular infections, it is not typically implicated in cases with the acute onset and severity described in the question.

Option C - Herpes simplex virus:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause viral keratitis, but the symptoms and signs associated with HSV keratitis often involve a dendritic corneal ulcer rather than a rapidly progressing bacterial corneal ulcer. The timeline and characteristics of the ulcer described are not typical of HSV keratitis.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus can cause bacterial keratitis, but the rapid onset of symptoms and stromal edema may be more indicative of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is known for its aggressive and fast-progressing corneal infections.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with swelling and redness around his left eye. He complains of pain upon eye movement and has a low-grade fever. On examination, there is proptosis, restriction of extraocular movements, and tenderness to palpation. Imaging reveals opacification of the left ethmoid sinus. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Haemophilus influenzae:

  • The clinical picture of U/L involvement of the eye with low-grade fever, proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements suggests the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis and ethmoid sinus infection confirms the diagnosis. The most common organism associated with the development of orbital cellulitis in children is Haemophilus influenzae. This bacterium is a gram-negative coccobacillus and is a common pathogen in sinusitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is not the most common pathogen associated with orbital cellulitis in children.

Option C – Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in the general population whereas Haemophilus influenzae is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in the pediatric population.

Option D – Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli is not a common pathogen associated with orbital cellulitis. It is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following images correctly depicts proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 

 

  • This image correctly depicts Proliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification, showing large flame shaped hemorrhages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots, and there is a tuft of new blood vessels at the disc, marking it as a Neovascularization at disc.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 

  • In this image we can only see hard exudates, small flame shaped hemorrhage features of Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Option B - 

  • In this image we can see multiple cotton wool spots, large flame shaped hemorrhages, and large dot and blot hemorrhage making it as Moderate non-preproliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification

Option D -  

  • In this image we can see there is looping of vessels, blot hemorrhages, large dot hemorrhage and cotton wool spots features of moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about his vision. On examination, you notice dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva as shown in the image. The clinician says the dry foamy patch on the conjunctiva is a keratinized epithelium. Which side is more commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Temporal side:

  • The clinical picture in the question and image confirms the condition is Bitot's spot. Bitot's spots are a clinical manifestation of vitamin A deficiency and are characterized by dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva. The keratinized epithelium in Bitot's spots is more commonly found on the temporal side of the conjunctiva.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasal side: In Bitot's spots, the keratinized epithelium is not commonly found on the nasal side. Bitot's spots usually appear most commonly on the temporal side of the conjunctiva.

Option C – Inferiorly: Bitot's spots are not specifically associated with the inferior aspect of the conjunctiva. The characteristic dry, foamy patches are more commonly found on the lateral or temporal side.

Option D – Superiorly: Bitot's spots are not typically observed on the superior side of the conjunctiva. The temporal side is the more common location for the keratinized epithelium associated with Bitot's spots.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of dry eyes and occasional blurred vision. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On examination, the ophthalmologist suspects dry eye syndrome and decides to perform the Schirmer test. Which paper is used in the Schirmer test to assess the wet length?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Whatman paper:

  • In the Schirmer test, Whatman filter paper No. 41 is commonly used to measure tear production and assess dry eye syndrome. This standardized filter paper is designed to absorb tears, allowing for the measurement of the wet length as an indicator of tear production.

Incorrect Options:
Option A – Litmus paper: Litmus paper is typically used to test the acidity or alkalinity of a solution based on a color change. It is not used in the Schirmer test.

Option C – Wax paper: Wax paper is not used in the Schirmer test. It is a type of paper that has been coated with a thin layer of wax to make it moisture-resistant.

Option D – Parchment paper: Parchment paper is not used in the Schirmer test. It is a type of paper that is treated with sulfuric acid or zinc chloride to give it a smooth and non-stick surface.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology camp in a rural area with complaints of gradual visual loss in both eyes. The ophthalmologist asks his intern what is the most common cause of preventable blindness in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Cataract:

  • Cataract is the clouding of the eye's lens, leading to visual impairment. Cataracts are a major cause of preventable blindness worldwide and in India, and they are the leading cause of preventable blindness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Trachoma: Trachoma is a bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is the chronic conjunctivitis in children which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is the world's leading cause of preventable and irreversible blindness and is the second most common cause in India.

Option C – Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a group of conditions that are characterized by chronic progressive optic neuropathy that results in characteristic morphological changes at the optic nerve head and in the retinal nerve fibre layer. It is the most common cause of blindness in developed countries but not in India.

Option D – Refractive error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (near-sightedness), hypermetropia (far-sightedness), and astigmatism, can cause visual impairment. It is the second most common cause of blindness in India.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman complains of pain and stiffness in her hands, particularly in the morning. She notices swelling and warmth in multiple joints, and there is a mild deformity in the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. On examination, the following finding is noted:



Which of the following joints is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints:

  • The clinical presentation of pain, stiffness in the morning, swelling, and warmth in multiple joints, along with the presence of Heberden's nodes and Bouchard’s nodes, are indicative of osteoarthritis (OA), particularly in the hands.
  • Heberden's nodes are bony enlargements that occur at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, which are the joints closest to the fingertips. These nodes are a characteristic feature of osteoarthritis affecting the hand joints.
  • In osteoarthritis of the hands, the DIP joints are commonly involved, leading to the development of Heberden's nodes. Osteoarthritis primarily affects the articular cartilage, leading to joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and bony changes such as the development of Heberden's nodes.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are less likely to be affected in the described clinical scenario. Osteoarthritis typically involves weight-bearing joints such as the knees and hips, but the presence of Heberden's nodes points toward the involvement of the DIP joints in this case.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness in his left big toe. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of similar symptoms in multiple joints, including the knees and ankles. On examination, the affected joint is warm, and tender, and has a limited range of motion. Laboratory analysis is given:


	
		
			Test Name
			Result
		
		
			Uric acid
			9.5
		
	


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Gout:

  • Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by the sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness, typically affecting the joint at the base of the big toe. It is caused by the deposition of urate crystals in the joints and surrounding tissues. Individuals with gout often have elevated levels of serum uric acid, a byproduct of purine metabolism.
  • The classic presentation of acute gout involves the first metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra), but it can also affect other joints such as the knees and ankles. Recurrent episodes of gout may lead to the development of tophi, which are urate crystal deposits that can be palpated as nodules under the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteoarthritis:

  • It is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage, leading to pain and stiffness.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • It is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium of joints, causing inflammation and joint damage.

Option C - Psoriatic arthritis:

  • It is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the distal radius with a dinner fork deformity. An X-ray is given:



What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Closed reduction and cast immobilization:

  • Colles' fracture is a type of distal radius fracture that typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand. It is characterized by dorsal angulation and radial shortening, leading to the classic appearance of a dinner fork deformity on examination. The initial management of a displaced Colles' fracture involves closed reduction, followed by cast immobilization.
  • Closed reduction is performed to realign the fractured fragments and restore anatomical alignment. This is often achieved by applying traction and manipulation to the fractured limb. Once the reduction is successful, a cast is applied to maintain the alignment and provide stability to the fracture site during the healing process.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Open reduction and internal fixation:

  • It may be considered in certain cases where closed reduction is not successful or if there are associated complications such as intra-articular involvement. However, closed reduction is generally the first-line approach.

Option C - Application of a splint:

  • It may be used temporarily for pain control and initial stabilization, but it is not the definitive management for a displaced Colles' fracture.

Option D - Observation and analgesia:

  • Without any intervention would not be appropriate for a displaced Colles' fracture, as it may lead to malunion and functional impairment.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with persistent pain and swelling in his left thigh for the past several weeks. On examination, there is localized tenderness and a palpable mass. Radiographs show a permeative lytic lesion with an "onion-skin" appearance. MRI reveals a soft tissue mass extending from the diaphysis into the surrounding soft tissues. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Immediate amputation of the affected limb
Chemotherapy followed by wide surgical excision
Radiation therapy as the primary treatment

questions.solution:
Correct B - Chemotherapy followed by wide surgical excision:

  • The clinical presentation and imaging findings described are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma, a malignant bone tumor that often affects children and adolescents. The "onion-skin" appearance on radiographs and the soft tissue mass extending from the diaphysis on MRI are characteristic features.
  • The most appropriate next step in the management of Ewing's sarcoma is chemotherapy followed by wide surgical excision. Ewing's sarcoma is a highly aggressive tumor, and the standard treatment approach involves a combination of chemotherapy and local control with surgery or radiation therapy.
  • Chemotherapy is typically initiated first to target micrometastatic disease and shrink the primary tumor. After a course of chemotherapy, surgical excision of the primary tumor with clear margins is performed whenever possible. The goal is to achieve local control and prevent recurrence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immediate amputation of the affected limb:

  • This is not the standard initial approach for Ewing's sarcoma. Limb-sparing surgery, combined with chemotherapy, is preferred to preserve function and quality of life.

Option C - Radiation therapy as the primary treatment:

  • It may be considered in certain cases, but it is often used as an adjunct to surgery and chemotherapy.

Option D - Observation with serial imaging:

  • It is not appropriate for Ewing's sarcoma due to its aggressive nature, and delayed intervention could lead to disease progression.

questions.text: Which of the following CD markers is commonly associated with B cells and plays a significant role in signal transduction, facilitating B cell receptor activation and subsequent immune responses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CD79a, CD79b:

  • CD79a and CD79b are signal transduction molecules associated with B cells. These molecules form the CD79 complex, also known as the Ig-alpha/Ig-beta heterodimer, which is part of the B cell receptor complex. The CD79 complex is involved in transmitting signals from the B cell receptor (BCR) to the interior of the B cell, leading to B cell activation and immune responses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CD10 (CALLA):

  • Refers to CD10 (CALLA), which is a marker for common acute lymphoblastic leukemia antigen and is found on B cells.

Option B - CD19:

  • Refers to CD19, which is a pan B cell marker and is important for B cell development and function.

Option C - CD20:

  • Refers to CD20, which is another B cell marker and is the target of monoclonal antibody therapies used in certain B cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins is responsible for ADP ribosylation of GTP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Cholera toxin:

  • Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae. It causes ADP ribosylation of the G protein subunit, leading to the persistent activation of adenylate cyclase and increased intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP). This results in the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, leading to the watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Shiga toxin:

  • Shiga toxin is produced by certain strains of Escherichia coli bacteria. It inhibits protein synthesis by specifically modifying the 28S subunit of the eukaryotic ribosome but does not involve ADP ribosylation of GTP.

Option B - Diphtheria toxin:

  • Diphtheria toxin is produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), preventing the transfer of amino acids to the growing polypeptide chain.

Option C - Botulinum toxin:

  • Botulinum toxin, produced by Clostridium botulinum, inhibits the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. It does not involve ADP ribosylation of GTP.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms shows attachment/effacement lesions as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – EPEC:

  • The organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells is EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • Enteropathogenic E.coli (EPEC) causes attaching and effacing lesions.
  • Paediatric age group diarrhoea (infantile) by attaching to enterocytes and causing their effacement.
  • Factors which promote attachment and effacement (loss of microvilli) are:
  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by a plasmid EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).

Incorrect Options:

Option B – ETEC:

  • ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) causes attachment through CFA (colonization factor antigen).

Option C – EHEC:

  • EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli) causes VT (verotoxin) mediated capillary microangiopathy.

Option D - V. Cholerae.:

  • Vibrio cholerae lives in contaminated water.
  • It enters the human body by the consumption of uncooked seafood (e.g., raw shellfish).
  • Cholera toxin (enterotoxin) is a protein that causes “rice-water” diarrhoea.
  • It causes bacterial gastroenteritis.

questions.text: HPV 16 and 18 subtypes of HPV has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix. Which of the following structure of HPV is responsible for causing carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – E6 and E7:

  • Rb gene (early gene) controls early viral production during the infection period.
  • Products of E6 and E7 interfere with p53 and Rb genes, as a result of this interference, cause:
  • Immortalization and malignant transformation of keratinocytes.
  • Keratinocytes that are immortalized histomorphological display hallmarks of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions and become precursors of cervical carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – E4 and E5:

  • E4 and E5 are responsible for making a change in the cell called Koilocytosis.

Option B – E2:

  • E2 is a regulatory protein involved in the control of viral replication and transcription. While it plays a role in the HPV life cycle, it is not directly responsible for the oncogenic transformation leading to carcinoma.

Option D – L1:

  • L1 is the major capsid protein of HPV and is primarily involved in the formation of the viral capsid. It is not associated with the cellular changes that lead to carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the most likely identification of the parasitic infection in a 28-year-old traveler with abdominal pain, bloody mucus in stools, and fever. A histopathological finding is observed as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Entamoeba histolytica:

  • The clinical presentation of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, fever, and histological finding of flask shaped ulcer are consistent with Entamoeba histolytica.

Flask Shaped Ulcer:

  • Damages the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Can't damage the muscularis as it is difficult to break.
  • Thus, it starts breaking submucosa on left and right.
  • Resulting in flask shaped ulcer.
  • Inside flask shaped ulcers- Trophozoites are seen.
  • Trophozoites have 1 big nucleus and small engulfed RBCs (Erythrophagocytosis).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia lamblia:

  • Giardia does not exhibit the described features, and it causes watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea.

Option C - Cryptosporidium parvum:

  • Cryptosporidium parvum can cause diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not exhibit the described trophozoite morphology.

Option D - Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan that causes genitourinary infections and does not have the features mentioned.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with fever, vomiting, neck rigidity, and rash. The doctor sends the patient lab tests. On microscopy, lens-shaped gram-negative cocci are seen. Biochemical tests of this organism show glucose and maltose fermentation. What can be the most dreadful complication seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Waterhouse Friderichsen syndrome:

  • This clinical scenario and sample microscopy indicate Meningococcal meningitis. Maltose and glucose fermentation is specific for this class of bacteria. Fever, vomiting, headache, neck rigidity, and rash are typical symptoms.
  • The Most common severe complication of Meningococcal infection is Water-House Friderichsen syndrome causing bilateral adrenal hemorrhagic necrosis. In this syndrome, adrenal glands fail to function normally.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Water-can perineum:

  • It is a condition that results in the multiple fistulae extending from the urethra to open inside the perineum.
  • They can result as a result of chronic inflammatory strictures. They are primarily seen in gonorrheal infections.

Option B - Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome:

  • It is a syndrome in which inflammation of the liver capsule occurs associated with adhesion formation, resulting in pain in the right upper quadrant.

Option C – Polyarthritis:

  • It is used when at least five or more joints are involved with pain and discomfort. Swelling, warmth, and redness are typical physical presentations.
  • This condition is mainly caused by an auto-immune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. But it can also be caused due to alphavirus.

questions.text: What does the presence of a visible precipitin line in the Elek's gel precipitation test between the antitoxin filter paper and the patient's sample suggest in the suspected case of diphtheria?

choices.text: The patient has diphtheria caused by toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
The patient has diphtheria caused by non-toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
The patient does not have diphtheria, as no precipitin line was seen with the antitoxin.
The patient has a non-diphtheria bacterial infection that is producing a similar toxin.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The patient has diphtheria caused by toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae:

  • The Elek's gel precipitation test is used to determine the presence of diphtheria toxin in a patient's sample. It involves placing one filter papers on an agar plate containing C. diphtheria antitoxin, and then we will put 3 more filter paper over the previous filter paper one with corynebacterium diphtheria toxin, there will be precipitin line formation, and one with non-toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheria there will be no line formation, and third strip has patients isolate.
  • If the patient's sample contains diphtheria toxin, a precipitin line will form between the antitoxin filter paper and the patient's sample. The formation of a visible precipitin line indicates the presence of diphtheria toxin, confirming the diagnosis of diphtheria caused by toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - The patient has diphtheria caused by non-toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheria:

  • It is incorrect, as there would be no precipitin line seen with the non-toxigenic strain, ruling out diphtheria in this case.

Option C - The patient does not have diphtheria, as no precipitin line was seen with the antitoxin:

  • It is incorrect because the presence of a precipitin line indicates the presence of diphtheria toxin, confirming the diagnosis of diphtheria.

Option D - The patient has a non-diphtheria bacterial infection that is producing a similar toxin:

  • It is incorrect because the Elek's test specifically detects diphtheria toxin, not toxins produced by other bacterial infections.

questions.text: Which of the following disinfectant agent works by liberating free hydroxyl radicals to set the apparatus free from microorganisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hydrogen peroxide:

  • Hydrogen peroxide works by liberating free hydroxyl radicals.
  • Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a mild antiseptic.
  • It is a strong oxidiser [high-level disinfectant]: It liberates toxic free hydroxyl radicals and active ingredients.
  • Attack membrane, DNA, lipid & other cellular components

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Formaldehyde:

Forms:

  • Gas → used for OT fumigation.
  • Liquid (Formalin) → used to preserve anatomical & pathological specimens.

Option C - Heavy metals:

  • Heavy metals combine with bacterial cell proteins, often with their sulfhydryl groups, and inactivate them.
  • They may also precipitate cell proteins.
  • Most heavy metals are bacteriostatic.

Examples:

  • Silver sulfadiazine [used For burns]
  • Silver nitrate [1%]

Option D - Ethylene oxide:

  • Ethylene oxide sterilizer is one of the most widely used gaseous chemical sterilants.
  • It has high penetration power.
  • Has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity.

questions.text: Erythroblastosis fetalis, resulting from Rh incompatibility during pregnancy, is an example of which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type-II:

  • Erythroblastosis fetalis is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Erythroblastosis Fetalis: This condition develops when maternal antibodies specific for fetal blood group antigens cross the placenta and destroy fetal RBCs.
  • This condition is seen in cases where a pre-sensitized Rh-negative mother mounts an immune response against Rh-positive RBCs of the fetus.
  • This results in severe hemolysis, leading to anaemia and hyperbilirubinemia, which can even be fatal.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Type-I

  • Commonly called an allergic or immediate hypersensitivity reaction.
  • It occurs in 2 phases: Early phase and delayed phase
  • Early phase: Occurs within 2 hrs, release of preformed mediators like histamine and & tryptase.
  • Delayed phase: Occurs after 2 hrs to 24 hrs due to eosinophils.

Option C: Type-III

  • Type-III hypersensitivity reactions result from the excess formation of immune complexes (Ag-Ab complexes), which initiate an inflammatory response through activation of the complement system leading to tissue injury.

Option D: Type-IV

  • It is delayed-type (after 48–72 hours of antigen exposure).
  • Cell-mediated: Characteristic cells called TDTH cells (Th cells involved in the delayed hypersensitivity) are the principal mediators.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presented to the emergency department following an accidental burns injury. It was identified as a superficial second-degree burn. Which of the following is seen in this category of burn?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blanch to touch:

  • Second-degree burns are also known as Partial thickness burn
  • Blanch to touch is a feature seen in a superficial second-degree burn

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Involvement of epidermis + Reticular dermis:

  • Involvement of epidermis + Reticular dermis is consistent with deep second-degree burn
  • Involvement of epidermis + Papillary dermis is seen in superficial second-degree burn

Option B - Pinprick sensation is preserved:

  • Pinprick sensation is preserved in a deep second-degree burn

Option D - Healing occurs with scarring:

  • Healing occurs with scarring in a deep second-degree burn

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with concerns regarding a lump in her neck. On examination, the lump is on the anterior part of the neck towards the midline. A histopathology image has been shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this disease?

choices.text: Most common route of spread: Hematogenous.
Commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades.
Most common site of metastasis: Lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Most common site of metastasis: Lungs:

  • The above histopathological image shows Optically clear nuclei (Also known as Orphan Annie eye nuclei), Pseudo-inclusion bodies, dystrophic calciﬁcation (Also known as Psammoma Bodies) which are seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma.
  • The most common site of metastasis in papillary thyroid carcinoma is the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most common route of spread: Hematogenous: Most common route of spread: Lymphatic (Because level 6 lymph nodes are involved) not hematogenous.

Option B - Commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades: It is not commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades

Option C - 2nd most common thyroid malignancy: It is the Most common thyroid malignancy, not 2nd most common.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is soft, ﬂuctuant, and shows transillumination positive. Which of the following is the commonest site for this?

choices.text: Junction of anterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid
Junction of posterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid
Junction of anterior upper and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.
Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid:

  • Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.
  • The commonest site of branchial cysts is indeed in this location. Branchial cysts are often found in the Junction of the upper and middle 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, near its attachment to the mastoid process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Junction of the anterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts do not commonly occur in this location.

Option B - Junction of posterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts do not commonly occur in this location either.

Option C - Junction of anterior upper and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts are not typically found in this specific location.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of non-healing wound on the lateral side of the thigh. She also has a history of accidental splatter of boiling water 9 months ago in the same area. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this scar?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Painful:

  • A non-healing scar in the previously burned injury area points towards the diagnosis of Marjolin's ulcer.
  • It is a painless scar not painful as there are no nerves in the scar tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No regional LN metastasis: There is no regional LN metastasis and there would be no lymphatics in scar tissue.

Option B - Slow Growing: Marjolin's ulcer is a slow-growing scar as it is avascular.

Option C - Radio resistant: Marjolin's ulcer is Radio resistant (avascular scar).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of lower abdomen pain radiating to the scrotum and perineal region. The pain is colicky in nature. Further evaluation reveals the presence of a 3 cm renal stone. An image of the stone is given below. What would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – PCNL:

  • If stone in the Lower 1/3rd of the ureter, pain radiates to (Via ilioinguinal nerve)
    • Scrotum
    • Perineum.
    • Inner aspect of thigh
  • The image is of a brushite stone which is a hard stone
  • The most appropriate treatment would be PCNL(Percutaneous nephrolithotomy) as the stone size is >2cm 

Incorrect options:

Option A – ESWL:

  • For stones of size up to 2 cm - ESWL is used
  • Hard stones like brushite cannot be broken down by ESWL

Option C – LSS:

  • LSS (Laparoscopic stone surgery): Not commonly preferred

Option D - Conservative management:

  • Conservative management is done for Stone size up to 5mm.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female presents to the clinic for a routine checkup as she underwent cholecystectomy 14 months ago. Blood examination was done which showed deranged LFT parameters:

ALP: 236 IU/L

GGT:98 U/L

5' nucleotidase:27 µ/l

She is otherwise well. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – MRCP:

  • The history of cholecystectomy with asymptomatic elevation of ALP (alkaline phosphatase), GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) , 5' nucleotidase leads to the diagnosis of CBD stone.
  • Investigation of choice – MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography)

Incorrect Options:

Option A – ERCP:

  • Gold standard investigation – ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is also the treatment for stones up to 1.5cm.

Option C – PTC:

  • PTC (Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography) is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It is used to:
    • Remove the stone from the proximal part of the bile duct, the intrahepatic bile duct.
    • Locate stent for proximal biliary strictures

Option D – USG:

  • USG can be done but it is not an investigation of choice for Choledocholithiasis

questions.text: A 43 year old male who was previously treated for traumatic injury now presented with severe wound pain. After further examination, Thin, brown, sweet smelling exudate from wound with crepitus were observed.He is a diabetic patient for past 15 years. Which of the following would have most commonly caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clostridium perfringens:

  • The image and the clinical features are suggestive of gas gangrene.
  • The most common organism responsible – is Clostridium perfringens (anaerobe).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clostridium sordellii: Clostridium sordellii can also cause gas gangrene but is not the most common cause.

Option C - Clostridium difficile: Clostridium difficile causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus does not cause gas gangrene.

questions.text: A neonate presented with drooling of saliva from mouth within a few hours of birth with a maternal history of Polyhydramnios. At the presentation, the baby had mild respiratory distress. Further evaluation shows Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) without Esophageal atresia. The presentation comes under which category of TEF?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Type E:

  • Type E ﬁstula TEF without EA which is also known as H-shaped ﬁstula

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Type A: Type A -Isolated esophageal atresia without Tracheoesophageal fistula.

Options B - Type B: Type B -Esophageal atresia with proximal Tracheoesophageal fistula.

Options C - Type D: Type D: proximal and distal TEF

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Bisgaard's Regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intermittent pneumatic compression:

  • Bisgaard's Regimen is done to manage venous ulcers in varicose vein
  • Intermittent pneumatic compression is not a component of Bisgaard's Regimen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Limb elevation: Limb elevation is a component of Bisgaard's Regime

Option B – Massage: Massage is a component of Bisgaard's Regime

Option C - Compression stockings: Compression stockings are a component of Bisgaard's Regime

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with discomfort and swelling in the scrotal region becomes more prominent in a standing position. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation is felt. Which of the following is a predisposing factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nutcracker's phenomenon:

  • The left renal vein compressed between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery is a predisposing factor for varicocele

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pagetoid phenomenon: Pagetoid phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

Option B - Bell clapper phenomenon: Bell clapper phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

Option D - Raynaud's phenomenon: Raynaud's phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lanes Forceps:

Incorrect Options:

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents with yellowish discoloration of skin and abdomen pain. Her vitals are

Temperature: 100 F

BP: 76/47 mm Hg

PR:101 bpm

She appears to be disoriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following best describes these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Reynold's Pentad:

Reynold's Pentad

  • Reynold's pentad characterized by
    • Charcot's triad
    • Shock
    • Mental status changes

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Saint Triad: Cholelithiasis (gallstones), hiatal hernia, diverticular disease (diverticulosis of colon).

Option B - Charcot's Triad: Charcot's triad is a clinical term used to describe a combination of symptoms associated with acute cholangitis, which is inflammation of the bile ducts. The classic triad consists of Abdominal pain, Fever, and Jaundice.

Option D - Renault's Triad: It is a term used in the context of traumatic spinal cord injuries and consists of three signs: flaccid paralysis, loss of sensation, and loss of deep tendon reflexes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents to ER with severe agonizing pain the the right scrotum associated with nausea and 2 episodes of vomiting. Prehn's sign is negative with absent cremasteric reﬂex. Which of the following is the IOC for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Doppler:

  • IOC is doppler

Incorrect Options:

Option A – USG: USG is not the IOC for testicular torsion

Option B - Duplex scan: Duplex scan is not the IOC for testicular torsion

Option C – Angiography: Angiography is not the IOC for testicular torsion

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting after the first feed. On the x-ray abdomen, a double bubble sign is seen which is suggestive of duodenal obstruction. In which type the windsock deformity is seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Type 1:

  • Duodenal atresia Occurs as a result of failure of vacuolization of duodenum from its solid cord stage.
  • Type 1:web (windsock deformity) - there is presence of duodenal diaphragm.

Incorrect Options

Option B - Type 2: Two ends are separated by a ﬁbrous cord.

Option C - Type 3: Complete separation of two ends.

Option D - Type 4: Only 3 types are there. There is no type 4.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge in the perianal region. Which of the following is the most common type according to park classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inter- sphincteric:

  • Park's classiﬁcation is related to ﬁstula-in-ano.
  • There are 4 types according to Park's classiﬁcation. Inter- sphincteric is the most common type.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trans- sphincteric: Trans- sphincteric is not the most common type of ﬁstula-in-ano

Option C - Supra- sphincteric: Supra- sphincteric is not the most common type of ﬁstula-in-ano

Option D - Extra- sphincteric: Extra-sphincteric is not the most common type of ﬁstula-in-ano

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of chest pain after forceful vomiting multiple times. On examination, cervical subcutaneous emphysema is observed. He is a chronic alcoholic. Which of the following will be seen in the chest x-ray of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Hydropneumothorax:

  • The above symptoms are characterized by Mackler's triad seen in Boerhaave Syndrome:
    • Thoracic Pain
    • Vomiting
    • Cervical subcutaneous emphysema

On Chest X-ray, hydropneumothorax is seen

  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis is water-soluble contrast esophagram (Gastrograﬁn)

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Hydrothorax: On chest x-ray of Boerhaave Syndrome, hydropneumothorax is seen, not hydrothorax.

Option B – Pneumothorax: On chest x-ray Boerhaave Syndrome, hydropneumothorax is seen, not pneumothorax.

Option D – Hemothorax: On chest x-ray of Boerhaave Syndrome, hydropneumothorax is seen, not hemothorax.

questions.text: A 3 months old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the testis was found in the Superﬁcial Inguinal Pouch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate time for management for this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Orchidopexy-6 months:

  • Ectopic testis
    • Most common location: Superﬁcial Inguinal Pouch
    • Caused due to abnormality of the Gubernaculum
    • Surgical treatment: orchidopexy-6 months is the most appropriate time. It should not be delayed by 2 years.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Orchidopexy-5 months: Surgical treatment: orchidopexy-6 months to 2 years

Option C - Orchidopexy-3 years: Surgical treatment: orchidopexy-6 months to 2 years

Option D - Orchidopexy-5 years: Surgical treatment: orchidopexy-6 months to 2 years

questions.text: A 23-year-old male has a massive burn injury on his right thigh recently. He is scheduled to undergo a skin graft to manage the wound. Split-thickness skin graft for wound closure on the thigh includes which of the following?

choices.text: Epidermis and part of the dermis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epidermis and part of the dermis:

  • Split-thickness skin graft (STSG) is a surgical technique used to repair skin defects by transferring a thin layer of skin from a donor site to the recipient site. The graft includes the epidermis and a part underlying the dermis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epidermis and full dermis: epidermis and full dermis are included in full-thickness skin grafts and not split-thickness skin grafts.

Option C - Epidermis, dermis, and fat: Split-thickness skin grafts do not include the subcutaneous fat layer.

Option D - Epidermis only Split-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and a part underlying the dermis and not only the epidermis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of sudden and severe abdominal pain, with a history of persistent diarrhea and vomiting. He was diagnosed with MI 3 months ago. The patient was in a state of shock and urgent resuscitation was done. Which of the following signs is seen in the mesenteric arteriography of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - String of sausage sign:

  • A spasm in the vessel is called “STRING OF SAUSAGES is seen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - String of rod sign: String of rod sign is not seen in Acute Mesenteric Ischemia

Option C - String of pipe sign: String of pipe sign is not seen in Acute Mesenteric Ischemia

Option D - String of roll sign: String of roll sign is not seen in Acute Mesenteric Ischemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with a pounding headache, chest pain, and anxiety. BP is 167/101 mm Hg with diaphoresis. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - MEN 1A:

  • The above-mentioned features with hypertension and diaphoresis and headache with palpitation are consistent with pheochromocytoma
  • MEN 2A and 2B are a risk factors not MEN 1A

Incorrect Options:

Option B - vHL syndrome: vHL syndrome is a risk factor for pheochromocytoma

Option C - Von-Recklinghausen syndrome: Von-Recklinghausen syndrome is a risk factor for pheochromocytoma

Option D - Sturge-Weber Syndrome: Sturge-Weber Syndrome is a risk factor for pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 23-year-old male was brought to the ER by his team after he passed out while playing cricket. One of his team members said that he was feeling light-headed and palpitations before passing out. His elder brother had died recently due to cardiac arrest at a very young age. An ECG was done as shown below. What is the most appropriate management strategy?

choices.text: Refer for immediate radiofrequency catheter ablation

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Refer for immediate radiofrequency catheter ablation:

  • Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized by an accessory pathway that allows for abnormal conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to a predisposition for supraventricular tachycardias, including atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT). Radiofrequency catheter ablation is the treatment of choice for WPW syndrome, as it targets and eliminates the abnormal accessory pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administer intravenous adenosine:

  • Adenosine is not typically used in WPW
  • Adenosine is contraindicated in WPW syndrome. While adenosine is commonly used to terminate supraventricular tachycardias, it acts by blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node. In WPW syndrome, the accessory pathway bypasses the AV node, and administration of adenosine can actually increase conduction through the accessory pathway, potentially leading to life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation.

Option B - Initiate antiarrhythmic therapy with flecainide:

  • IV flecainide is given for prevention as a long-term management

Option C - Perform electrical cardioversion:

  • Electrical cardioversion is generally not the first-line treatment for WPW syndrome. It can result in very rapid ventricular rates due to conduction through the accessory pathway and may lead to hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea, and weight loss. Which of the following is the earliest feature seen on barium enema for this patient?

LAB parameters are as follows

pANCA +

Hb: 8.3

MCV:76 fl

RDW:14.5%
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Granular appearance:

In ulcerative colitis,

  • Barium enema: Earliest feature is Granular appearance due to pseudo polyps This granular appearance is a result of mucosal inflammation and ulceration in the colon.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cobblestone appearance:

  • Cobblestone appearance is typically associated with Crohn's disease, not ulcerative colitis. In Crohn's disease, transmural inflammation can lead to a cobblestone-like appearance on imaging studies.

Option C - Pseudomembrane formation:

  • Pseudomembrane formation is more characteristic of pseudomembranous colitis, which is usually caused by Clostridium difficile infection. It is not a typical finding in ulcerative colitis.

Option D - Loss of haustration:

  • The earliest feature of barium enema is the Granular appearance due to pseudo polyps; loss of Haustrations leading to LEAD PIPE COLON appearance is seen later.

questions.text: A physician encounters a patient with symptoms indicative of meningococcal meningitis. The physician, at risk due to the mode of transmission through droplets, becomes infected. His mother and wife who is 4 months pregnant are taking care of him. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylaxis for his mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ciproﬂoxacin:

  • Neisseria meningitidis causes epidemics of meningitis in winter in an overcrowded population.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ceftriaxone:

  • Health workers and pregnant women are given Ceftriaxone

Option C- - Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin has 70% eﬃcacy and is not recommended for healthcare workers.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin

Option D - Penicillin G:

  • Penicillin G is not mentioned as a preferred prophylactic agent for meningococcal meningitis, and it is not specifically recommended for family contacts in this scenario. Ciprofloxacin is a more appropriate choice for this purpose.

questions.text: 60-year-old patient presents to the hospital with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. The patient was unable to resist blinking when the doctor tapped repetitively on the area of skin between the eyebrows. Which of the following signs is depicted by the physician?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Myerson sign:

  • Myerson sign, also known as the "glabellar tap sign," is a neurological sign characterized by the inability to suppress the blink reflex when the forehead is tapped repeatedly. This is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease.
  • In the case described, the 60-year-old patient with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability is exhibiting a positive Myerson sign, indicating dysfunction in the basal ganglia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Babinski Sign: The Babinski sign is a neurological reflex that involves the dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of the other toes in response to the stimulation of the sole of the foot. This is not related to the described scenario and is associated with upper motor neuron lesions.

Option B - Chaddock Sign: The Chaddock sign is a variant of the Babinski sign where the response is elicited by stimulation along the lateral aspect of the foot. Like the Babinski sign, it is indicative of upper motor neuron dysfunction and is not relevant to the symptoms presented in the case.

Option C - Gordon Reflex: Gordon reflex, also called the paradoxical flexor reflex, is a clinical sign utilized to detect upper motor neuron lesions. Evaluation of this reflex is simple and rapid and does not require the use of any equipment. A positive Gordon reflex suggests an upper motor neuron lesion, denoted by an extensor plantar response that occurs when the calf is squeezed. A positive Gordon test can appear similar to a Babinski sign in an adult, and both procedures evaluate for upper motor neuron lesions.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements.

1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome

2. MEN 1 is also known as Werner syndrome

3. MEN 2B is characterized by the presence of Marfanoid Habitus.

4. MEN 4 is a/w CDKN1B
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2,3,4:

  1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome: This statement is false. MEN 2B is not known as Sipple syndrome. Sipple syndrome is associated with multiple endocrine adenomatosis type 2A (MEN 2A).
  2. MEN 1 is also known as Wermer syndrome: This statement is TRUE. MEN 1 is associated with Wermer syndrome.
  3. Marfanoid Habitus is a feature of MEN 2B: This statement is true. Marfanoid habitus, which refers to the skeletal features similar to Marfan syndrome, is commonly seen in individuals with MEN 2B.
  4. MEN 4 is associated with CDKN1B: This statement is true. MEN 4 is a rare form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is associated with mutations in the CDKN1B gene.

As, statements 2,3,4 are correct so Option D is the correct answer to the question.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1,3: As statement 1 is incorrect so option A is incorrect.

Option B - 1,2: As statement 1 is incorrect so option B is incorrect.

Option C - 1,2,3: As statement 1 is incorrect so option C is incorrect.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with complaints of pain, tenderness, and stiffness in her wrists and fingers after she wakes up in the morning. After further evaluation, the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis was made and treatment was started. Which of the following would be the correct statement regarding rheumatoid nodules if present in this patient?

choices.text: Tender, located on the extensor surface
Non-tender, located on the extensor surface
Non-tender, located on the flexor surface
Tender, located on the flexor surface

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non-tender, located on the extensor surface:

  • Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous nodules that are a characteristic feature of rheumatoid arthritis. They are usually painless (non-tender) and are typically found over bony prominences, especially on the extensor surfaces of joints, such as the elbows. Rheumatoid nodules result from the accumulation of inflammatory cells and fibrous tissue and are a specific clinical manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Tender, located on the extensor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are non-tender, not tender.

Option C - Non-tender, located on the flexor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are not typically found on the flexor surfaces.

Option D - Tender, located on the flexor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are non-tender, not tender.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease, diabetes mellitus and HTN presents to the emergency with a complaint of nausea, abdominal pain, and lethargy.

PH=7.2, PO2=56mm Hg, PCO2 = 40 mmHg,spo2: 98% on Room Air.

HCO3 =15 meq (22-26 meq), urine ketones: ++, and RBS = 366 mg/dl

Which of the following types of insulin should be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Regular insulin:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with symptoms suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is characterized by high blood glucose levels, metabolic acidosis, and ketosis. DKA is considered a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment with insulin.
  • Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, is the most appropriate choice for managing DKA.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Rapid-acting insulin: Rapid-acting insulin is commonly used to manage postprandial glucose spikes in individuals with diabetes. However, in the context of DKA, regular insulin is preferred due to its longer duration of action.

Option C - Long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin provides a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). It is used for basal insulin coverage and does not have a rapid onset or peak effect, making it less suitable for managing acute hyperglycemia and acidosis in DKA.

Option D - Pre-mixed insulin: Pre-mixed insulin is less suitable for the management of DKA

questions.text: A 16 year old male presents with complaints of headache of sudden onset and also change in his urine color as given in the image below. He was taking antibiotics for a sore throat 2 weeks ago. Which of the following will be seen in light microscopy of kidney biopsy for this patient?

choices.text: Sub epithelial cell deposits as humps

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyper cellular glomerulus:

  • The patient is likely experiencing Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is supported by the history of sore throat two weeks ago and the current presentation with headache and cola-colored urine.
  • In PSGN, light microscopy typically reveals a hypercellular glomerulus, indicating an increased number of cells within the glomeruli.
  • Polymorphonuclear (PMN) infiltration is a characteristic feature seen in the glomeruli during PSGN.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - C3 deposits:

  • This is associated with immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, but PSGN is primarily a result of antigen-antibody complexes involving streptococcal products.
  • The correct characteristic for PSGN is PMN infiltration rather than specific immunoglobulin or complement deposits.

Option C - Subepithelial cell deposits as humps:

  • This is more characteristic of membranous glomerulonephritis or type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not PSGN.
  • In PSGN, the deposits are typically subendothelial rather than subepithelial.

Option D - Podocyte effacement:

  • Podocyte effacement is a feature seen in nephrotic syndrome, where there is damage to the podocytes in the renal glomeruli. PSGN typically does not present with podocyte effacement.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the ER with recurrent episodes of vomiting, lethargy, and seizures. He underwent chemotherapy yesterday for ALL. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities will not be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Hypernatremia:

  • Hypernatremia is not typically associated with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). TLS is characterized by the rapid release of intracellular contents into the bloodstream, often occurring after chemotherapy, and commonly presents with hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia. However, an increase in serum sodium levels (hypernatremia) is not a direct consequence of tumor lysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia is a common finding in tumor lysis syndrome. It results from the breakdown of nucleic acids released during the lysis of cancer cells. Increased uric acid levels can lead to complications such as renal impairment and gout.

Option B - Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is a characteristic electrolyte abnormality in tumor lysis syndrome. The release of intracellular potassium from lysed cells can lead to elevated serum potassium levels, posing a risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
