Option C - Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia is commonly seen in tumor lysis syndrome. The released phosphate can form calcium phosphate precipitates in the renal tubules, leading to decreased serum calcium levels. Hypocalcemia can manifest with symptoms such as tetany, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 64 year old male patient with a previous history of stroke now is brought by his relatives as he is now unable to talk, eat or drink. He is able to move his eyes in a vertical direction only. He is not able to move his limbs.Which of the following part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pons, midbrain and medulla:

  • This patient is presenting with symptoms consistent with locked-in syndrome. Locked-in syndrome is a condition characterized by paralysis of all voluntary muscles in the body except for the vertical movement of the eyes. It typically results from damage to the lower brainstem, involving the pons, medulla, and sometimes the midbrain. In this case, the patient's inability to move his limbs, speak, or eat/drink is indicative of widespread brainstem involvement.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pons only: This option is incorrect because the patient's symptoms involve more than just the pons. The inability to move limbs and loss of speech and swallowing function suggest involvement of other brainstem regions.

Option B - Pons and medulla: This option is also incorrect. While the pons and medulla are both part of the brainstem and contribute to the presentation of locked-in syndrome, the midbrain is also involved in this case.

Option C - Pons and midbrain: This option is incorrect. Although both the pons and midbrain are affected in locked-in syndrome, the medulla is also involved, as indicated by the patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you complaining of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum testing reveals positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies.The test in the image below was positive, with a score of <5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Primary Sjogren's syndrome:

  • The patient's symptoms of dryness in the mouth and eyes, positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, and the positive Schirmer's test (wet length of less than 5 mm) without anesthesia are consistent with the diagnosis of Primary Sjogren's Syndrome.
  • This autoimmune condition primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to dryness in the eyes and mouth. The positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies further support the diagnosis.
  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is the deﬁciency of the aqueous layer.
  • KCS + Xerostomia primary: Primary Sjogren syndrome.
  • Schirmer's test 1 in the image involves placing Whatman paper No. 41 under the lower lid for 5 minutes: A wet length of less than 5 mm indicates dry eye. It measures both basal and reﬂex secretion.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Scleroderma:

  • Scleroderma antibodies are anti-Scl-70 and anti-centromere.
  • Scleroderma is another autoimmune connective tissue disorder, but it is not typically associated with dryness in the eyes and mouth. Instead, it is characterized by skin thickening, vascular abnormalities, and internal organ involvement.

Option C - Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome:

  • Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome can occur in conjunction with other autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. However, in this case, the patient's presentation and positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies suggest primary Sjogren's syndrome rather than secondary.
  • Primary Sjogren syndrome + connective tissue disorder: secondary Sjogren syndrome

Option D - Lacrimal Duct Stones:

  • Lacrimal duct stones are a mechanical obstruction in the tear drainage system and can cause tearing rather than dryness. The positive Schirmer's test and the presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are not consistent with lacrimal duct stones.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of ischemic heart disease and a previous myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations. On examination, he appears diaphoretic, and his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg with a heart rate of 180 beats per minute. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals was done as given below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Options D - IV Amiodarone:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient is presenting with chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations along with a rapid heart rate (ventricular tachycardia) on ECG. The patient is hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg. IV Amiodarone is an appropriate choice for the management of stable ventricular tachycardia. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can help in stabilizing the cardiac rhythm and preventing further episodes of ventricular tachycardia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV Adenosine:

  • Adenosine is commonly used for the termination of supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) like atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or atrial fibrillation/flutter. However, it is not effective in terminating ventricular tachycardia and may even worsen the condition.

Option B - Synchronized DC Shock:

  • Synchronized DC shock is generally reserved for hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. In this scenario, the patient is described as hemodynamically stable, and synchronized shocks are not the first-line intervention in such cases.

Option C - Asynchronized DC Shock:

  • Asynchronized DC shock is typically reserved for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, especially in the setting of cardiac arrest. In this scenario, the patient is hemodynamically stable, and asynchronized shocks are not the initial choice for a stable ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient reports a gradual onset of symptoms over the past 24 hours. On examination, the patient is visibly distressed, with the use of accessory respiratory muscles. Blood pressure measurements reveal a significant drop during inspiration, with a difference of 15 mmHg between the systolic blood pressure during expiration and inspiration. The patient's neck veins appear distended, and lung auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. The condition that the patient has presented is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Severe asthma:

  • Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): During severe asthma attacks or exacerbations of COPD, airway resistance increases significantly during inspiration. This leads to increased negative intrathoracic pressure, affecting venous return to the heart and causing a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Coronary artery disease: Coronary artery disease refers to the narrowing or blockage of the coronary arteries supplying blood to the heart muscle. While it can cause symptoms such as angina (chest pain) or myocardial infarction (heart attack), it is not directly associated with pulsus paradoxus.

Option C- Atrial Fibrillation: Atrial Fibrillation don not have pulsus paradoxus

Option D- Right ventricular myocardial infarction: Right ventricular myocardial infarction refers to a heart attack affecting the right ventricle of the heart. While myocardial infarction can cause various cardiovascular symptoms, pulsus paradoxus is not a characteristic feature of right ventricular myocardial infarction specifically

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a prosthetic mitral valve done 3 months ago presents to the clinic with a history of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and a low-grade fever. The patient reports a new-onset murmur on auscultation and occasional night sweats. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated inflammatory markers, and blood cultures are also sent. An echocardiogram demonstrates vegetation on the prosthetic valve. Which of the following organisms will be seen in blood culture for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS):

Explanation:

  • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) is an infection involving a prosthetic heart valve. The risk of PVE is highest in the first year after valve implantation. In this case, the patient has a prosthetic mitral valve placed 3 months ago and presents with symptoms suggestive of endocarditis, such as fatigue, unintentional weight loss, low-grade fever, new-onset murmur, and occasional night sweats. The echocardiogram reveals vegetation on the prosthetic valve.
  • The most common organism causing PVE between 2 and 12 months after valve implantation is Coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS). This is often attributed to factors like intraoperative contamination of the operating field or postoperative introduction of the organism. Therefore, CONS is a likely pathogen to be found in blood culture in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Staphylococcus aureus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of acute infective endocarditis, but it is less common in prosthetic valve endocarditis occurring 2-12 months after valve implantation. Coagulase-negative staphylococci are more frequently associated with late PVE.

Option C- Streptococcus viridans:

  • While Streptococcus viridans is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, it is not the most typical organism seen in prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially within the first year post-implantation.

Option D- Mycobacterium chimaera:

  • Mycobacterium chimaera is an atypical and rare cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis. It is not a common pathogen in routine cases and is usually associated with specific circumstances, such as exposure to contaminated heater-cooler units during cardiac surgery. It is not a typical organism to be expected in this patient's scenario.
  • Mycobacterium chimera has been responsible for the outbreak of prosthetic valve endocarditis in certain hospitals. Attributed to patients who are exposed to cardiopulmonary bypass machines with imperfect sterilization techniques followed in hospitals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with involuntary, rapid, jerky movements of her limbs and face. Her family reports behavioral changes over the past year, including irritability and social withdrawal. On examination, the patient exhibits choreiform movements, hyperreflexia, and cognitive impairment. Her father also had a similar condition. The gene involved is present in which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- 4:

  • The patient's symptoms such as choreiform movements, hyperreflexia, and cognitive impairment are diagnostic of Huntington Chorea
  • The Gene involved - the Huntington gene present on chromosome number 4.

Incorrect Options:

Option A-1: The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B-2:  The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C-3: The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient has been a long-time smoker and has a known history of recurrent exacerbations of COPD; he was put on a mechanical ventilator due to increasing dyspnea, fatigue, and altered mental status. On examination, the patient is found to be tachypneic, with labored breathing. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.28, PO2 - 100, PaCO2 of 60 mmHg, and a bicarbonate level of 32 mEq/L. What changes can be made to the ventilatory setting of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Increase the Minute volume:

  • In a patient with respiratory acidosis, like the one described in the scenario (low pH, elevated PaCO2), increasing the minute volume can be beneficial. Minute volume is the product of respiratory rate and tidal volume. By increasing the minute volume, more CO2 can be removed through ventilation, helping to correct respiratory acidosis. This adjustment is typically achieved by increasing the respiratory rate and/or tidal volume.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Decrease the Respiratory Rate:

  • Explanation: Decreasing the respiratory rate would be counterproductive in a patient with respiratory acidosis. A lower respiratory rate would reduce the amount of ventilation and, consequently, hinder the elimination of CO2. This would exacerbate respiratory acidosis.

Option C- Increase FIO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen):

  • Explanation: The patient's hypoxemia (PaO2 of 100) is not the primary concern in this case. The main issue is respiratory acidosis due to the elevated PaCO2. Increasing the fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) would address hypoxemia but would not directly impact the removal of CO2. Ventilatory adjustments are more appropriate for addressing the underlying respiratory acidosis.

Option D- Decrease PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure):

  • Explanation: PEEP is used to maintain alveolar recruitment and improve oxygenation in patients on mechanical ventilation. While PEEP can affect ventilation indirectly, decreasing it is not the primary intervention for correcting respiratory acidosis. In fact, reducing PEEP could potentially lead to atelectasis and worsen oxygenation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a sudden-onset severe headache associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. On examination, there was no focal neurological deficit however, neck rigidity was present. She has been on antihypertensives for 5 years. CT imaging is given below



Which of the following is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Subarachnoid hemorrhage:

  • The above image is that of subarachnoid hemorrhage and shows blood in the basal cistern. Trauma is the most common cause. The patient defines it as the worst headache of their life. It is also known as a thunderclap headache. It presents with neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness, and no focal neurological deficit.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is a venous bleed and CT shows a crescentic opacity.

Option B- Pituitary apoplexy: In pituitary apoplexy, there is sudden hemorrhage into the pituitary gland due to hematogenic hypoperfusion

Option D- Meningitis: Meningitis can also present with similar features but the CT image and severe headache of sudden onset is more likely SAH

questions.text: A 65-year-old alcoholic patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of palpitations, chest discomfort, and syncope. His PR is 240 bpm, BP: 70/50mmHg. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes, for which he takes medications irregularly. I/V esmolol has been given to this patient for rate control. Which of the following should be given next for rhythm control?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IV Amiodarone:

  • The above ECG and symptoms are suggestive of atrial fibrillation
  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication commonly used for rhythm control in patients with atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter, especially when there is hemodynamic instability. In this case, the patient presents with a rapid heart rate (PR of 240 bpm) along with symptoms such as palpitations, chest discomfort, and syncope. Esmolol has been administered for rate control, but for rhythm control, IV amiodarone is a suitable choice. Amiodarone is effective in converting atrial fibrillation/flutter to normal sinus rhythm and is often preferred in situations of hemodynamic compromise.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV Verapamil:

  • Verapamil is given for rate control but as esmolol has been administered already So ,there is no requirement of verapamil

Option B - Rivaroxaban:

  • Rivaroxaban is an anticoagulant and is not indicated for rhythm control. It is commonly used for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. While anticoagulation is an essential consideration in the management of atrial fibrillation, it does not directly address the rhythm control issue in this acutely symptomatic patient.

Option C - IV Flecainide:

  • Flecainide is another antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter. However, in a patient with hemodynamic instability and low blood pressure (BP: 70/50 mmHg), there is a risk of proarrhythmia with flecainide. Therefore, it is not the optimal choice in this scenario.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and confusion. His blood pressure is 200/120 mm Hg. On examination, the patient has bilateral papilledema, and fundoscopic examination reveals hemorrhages and exudates. Neurological examination shows signs of encephalopathy. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sodium nitroprusside:

  • When a known hypertensive patient arrives at the emergency room with signs of encephalopathy, it is important to manage their blood pressure promptly to prevent further complications. The initial step should be to reduce the blood pressure gradually, but not too quickly, using a medication that works quickly and has a short duration of action.
  • Sodium nitroprusside is the preferred drug for hypertensive encephalopathy

Incorrect Optinos:

Option A - Labetalol:

  • Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with alpha-blocking activity. While it is commonly used to manage hypertensive emergencies, it may not be the ideal choice in this specific scenario of hypertensive encephalopathy. Labetalol's onset of action may not be as rapid as sodium nitroprusside, and it has a longer duration of action.

Option B - Nicardipine:

  • Nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker that dilates arterial vessels, leading to a reduction in blood pressure. While it is suitable for hypertensive emergencies, it may not act as quickly as sodium nitroprusside, and its use may be more appropriate for cases where a gradual reduction in blood pressure is acceptable.

Option C - Mannitol:

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic medication, which is typically used as adjunctive therapy to reduce cerebral edema and intracranial pressure in various conditions, such as traumatic brain injury, cerebral edema due to malignancy, or cerebral aneurysm. It is not a first-line agent for hypertensive emergencies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 8 weeks presents to the obstetrician with complaints of palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. Diagnosis of Grave’s disease was confirmed after further evaluation. Which of the following can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Propylthiouracil:

  • Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, which results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland.
  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that works by inhibiting the production of thyroid hormones. PTU is the preferred drug for use during early pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, as it has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Methimazole: Methimazole is usually avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its potential risk of causing birth defects. However, it can be used during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy if PTU is not well-tolerated.

Option C - Carbimazole: Carbimazole is a prodrug of Methimazole. Like Methimazole, it is avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy due to the risk of causing birth defects.

Option D - Both B and C: As both option B and option C are incorrect so this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. She denies a history of excessive alcohol consumption. On examination, there is jaundice, hepatomegaly, and mild abdominal tenderness. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA), and Anti SMA antibodies. Which of the following is seen on the liver biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rosette formation:

  • The presence of rosette formation on liver biopsy is indicative of regenerating hepatocytes. In the context of the given clinical scenario of a 35-year-old woman with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) as well as Anti SMA antibodies, these findings are consistent with autoimmune hepatitis. Interface hepatitis, along with rosette formation, supports the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rouleaux Formation:

  • Rouleaux formation is a phenomenon in which red blood cells stack like a roll of coins. This is typically seen in conditions such as multiple myeloma, a plasma cell dyscrasia, and is not associated with autoimmune hepatitis.

Options C and D  - Ground Glass Hepatocytes and Hepatocytes Ballooning:

  • Ground glass hepatocytes and hepatocytes ballooning are characteristic findings seen in hepatitis B infection, not autoimmune hepatitis. Ground glass hepatocytes are indicative of intracellular accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen. Hepatocyte ballooning represents degenerative changes in hepatocytes, and these features are part of the histopathological spectrum observed in hepatitis B-induced liver injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department. On examination, he is visibly distressed, breathing rapidly, and using accessory muscles.FEV1 / FVC < 0.7 ,FEV1 = 30-50%. ABG shows a pH of 7.32, PaO2 of 60 mm Hg, PaCO2 of 50 mm Hg, and HCO3 of 26 mEq/L. All of the following are indications of NIV in this patient except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - PO2 <80mmHg:

  • The above scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of severe COPD
  • PO2 <80mmHg is not an Indication to start NIV in Severe COPD Exacerbation

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C - FEV1= 30-50%, pH <7.35 & PCO2 > 45mmHg:

All other options are Indications to start NIV in Severe COPD Exacerbation

  • FEV1= 30-50%
  • pH <7.35
  • PCO2 > 45mmHg

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents to the pulmonologist with a history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and a persistent cough. The patient has worked as a stone cutter in construction for the past 20 years. He reports a gradual onset of symptoms over the last decade and has noticed a decline in exercise tolerance. On physical examination, the pulmonologist observes clubbing of the fingers and bibasilar crackles on auscultation. Chest X-ray is given below



What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Silicosis:

  • Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica particles. It commonly affects individuals working in occupations such as mining, sandblasting, and stone cutting. And egg cell calcifications can be seen in the chest x-ray

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers.

Option C - Black lung disease: "black lung disease," is caused by the inhalation of coal dust.

Option D - Berylliosis: Berylliosis is a lung disease caused by exposure to beryllium, a metal used in various industries. berylliosis can cause granulomatous inflammation in the lungs

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to her gastroenterologist with complaints of chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and unintentional weight loss over the past several months. Laboratory tests show iron deficiency anemia, vitamin D deficiency, and elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies. Which of the following can she eat?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ragi:

  • Ragi, also known as finger millet, is a gluten-free grain. Given the patient's elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies and symptoms suggestive of celiac disease (chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, iron deficiency anemia, and vitamin D deficiency), a gluten-free diet is recommended. Ragi is a suitable choice in this scenario as it does not contain gluten, making it safe for individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rye: Rye contains gluten and is not recommended for individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity. It is a cereal grain that can exacerbate symptoms and contribute to the damage of the small intestine in individuals with gluten-related disorders.

Option C - Semolina: Semolina is a coarse flour made from durum wheat, and it contains gluten. Therefore, it is not suitable for individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity. Foods made from semolina, such as pasta and certain types of bread, should be avoided in a gluten-free diet.

Option D - Couscous: Couscous is made from crushed durum wheat and is another source of gluten. It is not recommended for individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity. Gluten-containing grains should be eliminated from the diet to manage symptoms and promote intestinal healing in these individuals.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of a malodorous vaginal discharge and mild irritation. On examination, the following picture is observed.



Microscopic examination of a wet mount reveals the presence of clue cells. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacterial vaginosis:

  • The clinical presentation of a thin, grayish-white, and adherent vaginal discharge, along with the absence of significant inflammation or erythema, is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora, with an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria and a decrease in lactobacilli.

  • The presence of clue cells on microscopic examination is a key diagnostic feature of bacterial vaginosis. Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, making them appear stippled or "clue-like" when observed under the microscope.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candidiasis:

  • It is associated with a thick, cottage cheese-like discharge and is caused by an overgrowth of Candida species. This presentation is not consistent with the clinical findings in this patient

Option B - Trichomoniasis:

  • It is characterized by a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. The clinical presentation described does not match the typical features of trichomoniasis.

Option D - Gonorrhea:

  • This typically presents with purulent discharge and is not the most likely cause of the symptoms described in this case

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. On hormonal evaluation, the patient is found to have an increased luteinizing hormone (LH): follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this hormonal profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age and is a leading cause of oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. One of the characteristic hormonal features of PCOS is an increased luteinizing hormone (LH): follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. In PCOS, there is an overproduction of luteinizing hormone (LH) relative to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), leading to disrupted ovarian function.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Primary Ovarian Failure:

  • It is characterized by a decreased ovarian function, leading to elevated levels of both LH and FSH. PCOS, on the other hand, is associated with elevated LH levels.

Option C - Hypothalamic Amenorrhea:

  • It typically presents with low levels of both LH and FSH due to a disruption in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. The LH:FSH ratio is not typically increased in hypothalamic amenorrhea

Option D - Hyperprolactinemia:

  • It can result in menstrual irregularities, but it is not associated with an increased LH:FSH ratio. Elevated prolactin levels suppress both LH and FSH.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. Her medical history reveals early initiation of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, and a history of smoking. She has not received the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine. What is the most significant predisposing factor for cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lack of HPV vaccination:

  • The most significant predisposing factor for cervical cancer is infection with high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is a sexually transmitted virus, and certain high-risk types, such as HPV 16 and 18, are strongly associated with the development of cervical cancer.

  • While all the factors mentioned (early initiation of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, and smoking) contribute to the overall risk of cervical cancer, the most significant and directly modifiable factor in this patient is the lack of HPV vaccination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Early initiation of sexual activity:

  • Early sexual activity is a risk factor for HPV exposure, but the primary concern is the acquisition of high-risk HPV strains.

Option B - Multiple sexual partners:

  • Having multiple sexual partners increases the risk of HPV exposure and infection with high-risk strains, contributing to the development of cervical cancer.

Option C - History of smoking:

  • Smoking is considered a cofactor in the development of cervical cancer. It may enhance the carcinogenic effects of HPV, but the lack of HPV vaccination is a more direct risk factor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports a positive home pregnancy test and a history of irregular menstrual cycles. On examination, she appears distressed, and pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an adnexal mass with no intrauterine gestational sac. The patient's vital signs are stable. What is the most likely site of ectopic pregnancy in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fallopian tube:

  • The clinical presentation of acute lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, cervical motion tenderness, and an adnexal mass on ultrasound, especially without an intrauterine gestational sac, strongly suggests an ectopic pregnancy. The fallopian tube, particularly the ampulla, is the most common site for ectopic pregnancies, accounting for approximately 95% of cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ovary:

  • Ectopic pregnancies rarely occur in the ovary. The ovary is not a favorable site for implantation.

Option B : Uterine fundus:

  • Implantation in the uterine fundus is characteristic of a normal intrauterine pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancies involve implantation outside the uterine cavity.

Option D - Cervix:

  • Ectopic pregnancies rarely occur in the cervix. Cervical pregnancies are uncommon and associated with a higher risk of severe bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea for several years. She describes the pain as deep, aching, and often worsening during menstruation. She also reports pain during sexual intercourse. The patient has a regular menstrual cycle and no significant gynecological history. On pelvic examination, there is tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix, and a fixed retroverted uterus is noted. Transvaginal ultrasound is given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct C - Endometriosis:

  • The patient's symptoms of chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and pain during sexual intercourse, along with the findings of tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix and a chocolate cyst on transvaginal ultrasound, are suggestive of endometriosis.

  • Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, leading to inflammation, scarring, and the formation of chocolate cysts (endometriomas). The symptoms often include pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and pain during sexual intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID):

  • While PID can cause pelvic pain, it is often associated with other symptoms such as fever, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness. The fixed retroverted uterus is not a typical finding in PID.

Option B - Ovarian cyst rupture:

  • While ovarian cyst rupture can cause acute pelvic pain, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the presence of a chocolate cyst (endometrioma) on ultrasound make endometriosis a more likely diagnosis.

Option D - Uterine fibroids:

  • Uterine fibroids can cause pelvic pain and abnormal uterine bleeding, but they are not typically associated with a fixed retroverted uterus or chocolate cysts on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of new-onset high blood pressure. She denies any history of hypertension or renal disease. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. There is no proteinuria on dipstick testing. Fetal monitoring reveals no signs of distress. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform a 24-hour urine collection for protein estimation
Immediate hospitalization for induction of labor
Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours:

  • This patient with new-onset high blood pressure at 34 weeks of gestation falls under the category of gestational hypertension. Gestational hypertension is defined as elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg) that develops after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria.
  • Management of gestational hypertension involves close monitoring to assess for the progression to preeclampsia, which is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria. In this case, the most appropriate next step is to repeat the blood pressure measurement after a short interval to confirm the diagnosis and assess for any signs of worsening hypertension or development of proteinuria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prescribe antihypertensive medication:

  • In the absence of severe hypertension or signs of end-organ damage, immediate initiation of antihypertensive medication is not the first-line approach. Close monitoring is initially recommended.

Option B - Perform a 24-hour urine collection for protein estimation:

  • This is not the immediate next step. Proteinuria is a key feature of preeclampsia, and if gestational hypertension progresses to preeclampsia, proteinuria may develop.

Option C - Immediate hospitalization for induction of labor:

  • Hospitalization and induction of labor are typically reserved for cases of severe gestational hypertension or preeclampsia with complications. In this case, with no signs of severe disease or fetal distress, immediate induction is not warranted.

questions.text: A 32-year-old couple presents to the fertility clinic with a history of infertility for the past 18 months. The husband reports a normal sexual history with no known medical conditions. The wife's menstrual cycles are regular, and her hormone levels are within normal limits. As part of the initial infertility workup, a semen analysis is ordered for the husband. The results reveal a low sperm count (oligospermia), decreased sperm motility, and a high percentage of morphologically abnormal sperm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome):

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome) is a condition characterized by low sperm count (oligospermia), decreased sperm motility (asthenospermia), and a high percentage of morphologically abnormal sperm (teratospermia). This combination of abnormalities in sperm quantity, motility, and morphology can contribute to male infertility.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Varicocele:

  • While a varicocele (enlarged veins in the scrotum) can impact sperm production and quality, it typically presents with a specific set of findings, such as a bag of worms sensation on palpation and is more commonly associated with increased spermatic vein reflux.

Option B - Obstructive azoospermia:

  • Obstructive azoospermia is characterized by the absence of sperm in the ejaculate due to a blockage in the reproductive tract. This condition is not typically associated with decreased sperm motility or abnormal morphology.

Option D - Retrograde ejaculation:

  • In retrograde ejaculation, semen is redirected into the bladder instead of being expelled from the penis. This condition is characterized by a lack of ejaculate and is not associated with abnormalities in sperm count, motility, or morphology.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure lasts for approximately 3 minutes. On regaining consciousness, the patient is noted to have elevated blood pressure (170/110 mmHg) and mild epigastric pain. Initial investigations reveal proteinuria on urine dipstick. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Administer magnesium sulfate:

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with eclampsia, a serious complication of preeclampsia characterized by the onset of seizures. The immediate management of eclampsia involves controlling seizures and preventing their recurrence, along with addressing the hypertensive crisis.
  • Magnesium sulfate is the first-line agent for seizure control in eclampsia. It acts as a central nervous system depressant and is effective in preventing and treating eclamptic seizures. It also has neuroprotective effects on the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Initiate antihypertensive therapy with labetalol:

  • While managing hypertension is important, antihypertensive therapy is not the immediate priority in the presence of ongoing seizures. Magnesium sulfate takes precedence for seizure control.

Option C - Perform an emergency cesarean section:

  • While delivery is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia and eclampsia, the immediate focus should be on stabilizing the patient and controlling seizures. Cesarean section is indicated if there is persistent maternal or fetal distress after initial stabilization.

Option D - Administer diazepam for seizure control:

  • Magnesium sulfate is the preferred agent for seizure control in eclampsia. Diazepam is an alternative, but magnesium sulfate is more commonly used due to its safety profile and additional benefits.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the postpartum unit after a vaginal delivery. Her pregnancy and labor were uneventful. The delivery was completed without complications, and the placenta was delivered intact. Approximately 30 minutes after delivery, the patient complains of increased vaginal bleeding. On examination, the fundus is firm, but the bleeding persists. Initial attempts to control bleeding with uterine massage and administration of oxytocin have been ineffective. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Perform a bimanual uterine examination:

  • This patient's presentation is concerning for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), defined as blood loss exceeding 500 ml after a vaginal delivery. In this case, the persistent bleeding despite a firm fundus suggests a possible source within the uterus, such as retained placental tissue.
  • A bimanual examination involves the insertion of one hand into the vagina to assess the uterus while the other hand is placed on the abdomen to palpate the fundus. This can help identify retained placental fragments or clots that may be causing the ongoing bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Administer methylergonovine:

  • Methylergonovine is a uterotonic medication that can be used to help control postpartum hemorrhage. However, the first step should be to identify the cause of the bleeding through a bimanual examination.

Option C - Insert a Bakri balloon:

  • A Bakri balloon is a device used for uterine tamponade in the management of postpartum hemorrhage. While it can be a valuable intervention, it is typically employed after the cause of bleeding has been identified.

Option D - Order a complete blood count (CBC):

  • While assessing the patient's blood count is important in the management of postpartum hemorrhage, the immediate priority is to identify and address the cause of the ongoing bleeding.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G3P2, at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports no antenatal complications until now. On examination, the uterus is tense, and there is tenderness on palpation. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the immediate management for this patient?

choices.text: Uterine atony; uterine massage and oxytocin

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Abruptio placenta; immediate delivery:

  • This patient's presentation is suggestive of abruptio placenta, where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall before delivery. The sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and signs of fetal distress are characteristic features. Immediate delivery is the management of choice in cases of abruptio placenta to mitigate the risk to both the mother and the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Placenta previa, initiate tocolysis:

  • Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding. In contrast, abruptio placenta is associated with painful bleeding and a tense uterus.

Option B - Uterine rupture, emergency cesarean section:

  • Uterine rupture may present with severe abdominal pain and signs of fetal distress, but it is not associated with the characteristic uterine tenderness seen in abruptio placenta.

Option D - Uterine atony, uterine massage and oxytocin:

  • Uterine atony, or failure of the uterus to contract, can cause postpartum hemorrhage but is not typically associated with sudden-onset abdominal pain and uterine tenderness seen in abruptio placenta.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and discomfort during intercourse. On pelvic examination, the physician notes tenderness in the rectouterine pouch and suspects the presence of a pelvic pathology. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis is a condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (endometrium) grows outside the uterus. It commonly involves the rectouterine pouch, also known as Douglas pouch or cul-de-sac. In endometriosis, the ectopic endometrial tissue can cause inflammation and scarring in the pelvic cavity, leading to tenderness and pain, particularly in the rectouterine pouch.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ovarian cyst:

  • While ovarian cysts can cause pelvic pain, they are less likely to specifically cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch.

Option C - Uterine fibroids:

  • Uterine fibroids are noncancerous growths of the uterus and are less likely to cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch.

Option D - Pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the female reproductive organs. While it can cause pelvic pain and tenderness, it may not specifically target the rectouterine pouch as seen in endometriosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of abnormal vaginal bleeding between menstrual cycles. She reports occasional pelvic discomfort but denies any pain during intercourse. On pelvic examination, a soft, less than 1 cm, reddish-purple, finger-like projection is noted on the cervix. The patient has no significant medical history, and Pap smear results from the previous year were normal. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Simple polypectomy:

  • The patient's presentation with abnormal vaginal bleeding, occasional pelvic discomfort, and the visual finding of a soft, less than 1cm, reddish-purple, finger-like projection on the cervix is consistent with a cervical polyp. Cervical polyps are benign growths that originate from the cervical canal or the surface of the cervix. They can cause irregular bleeding and may occasionally be associated with pelvic discomfort. The appropriate management for a cervical polyp is simple polypectomy. This procedure can often be performed in the office setting during a gynecological examination. The polyp is grasped and excised, and the specimen may be sent for histological examination to confirm its benign nature.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Referral for colposcopy : Colposcopy is not the primary management for a cervical polyp. Colposcopy is typically indicated for the evaluation of abnormal cervical cytology (Pap smear) or suspicion of cervical dysplasia or cancer.

Option C - Antibiotic therapy: Antibiotic therapy is not indicated for the management of cervical polyps. Cervical polyps are non-infectious, benign growths, and antibiotic therapy is not effective for their treatment.

Option D - Hysteroscopic resection : Hysteroscopic resection is a more invasive procedure and is typically reserved for the removal of larger intrauterine lesions, such as submucosal fibroids. It is not the first-line treatment for cervical polyps.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of upper abdominal pain, headache, and visual disturbances. She reports nausea and malaise over the past 24 hours. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg), and she has epigastric tenderness. Laboratory tests are given. What is the appropriate management in this case?


	
		
			
			Mean laboratory findings in the HELLP syndrome
			
		
		
			
			Hb%
			
			
			8.752 gm%
			
		
		
			
			Reticulocyte count (%)
			
			
			2.163
			
		
		
			
			Platelet count (cmm)
			
			
			94375
			
		
		
			
			LDH (u/l)
			
			
			1065.73
			
		
		
			
			Total bilirubin (mg/dl)
			
			
			3.17
			
		
		
			
			AST (u/l)
			
			
			146.34
			
		
		
			
			ALT (u/l)
			
			
			139.74
			
		
		
			
			Haemolysis in peripheral blood smear (n)
			
			
			38
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prompt delivery:

  • The diagnosis for this patient is HELLP syndrome. HELLP syndrome is a severe variant of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis (H), Elevated Liver enzymes (EL), and a Low Platelet count (LP). The patient's presentation with upper abdominal pain, headache, visual disturbances, nausea, malaise, elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg), epigastric tenderness, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and hemolysis is indicative of HELLP syndrome.

  • Prompt delivery is the mainstay of management for HELLP syndrome. Delivery is often recommended, even if the fetus is premature, as it is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications. The decision for delivery is based on the severity of the syndrome, gestational age, and the condition of both the mother and the fetus.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Antihypertensive therapy : While elevated blood pressure is a component of HELLP syndrome, the primary management is prompt delivery. Antihypertensive therapy may be used to manage hypertension but is not the main focus.

Option B - Magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis : Magnesium sulfate is typically used for seizure prophylaxis in cases of severe preeclampsia, but in the context of HELLP syndrome, the mainstay is prompt delivery.

Option D - Supportive care : Supportive care is important in the overall management, but the definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome is delivery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the obstetric clinic with concerns about a possible pregnancy. She reports missing her last menstrual period, experiencing breast tenderness, and feeling nauseous in the mornings. She also mentions increased frequency of urination. On examination, her breasts are mildly enlarged, and the areolas appear darker than usual. She denies any recent illness or changes in medication. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the most likely signs observed in this patient that support the diagnosis of pregnancy?

choices.text: Breast tenderness and darkening of areolas

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Breast tenderness and darkening of areolas:

  • The signs observed in this patient that support the diagnosis of pregnancy include breast tenderness and darkening of the areolas. Additionally, a positive urine pregnancy test further confirms the likelihood of pregnancy.

  • Breast tenderness is a common early sign of pregnancy, and changes in the areolas, such as darkening, are also characteristic. The combination of a missed menstrual period, breast tenderness, darkening of the areolas, and a positive urine pregnancy test strongly suggests early pregnancy.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Enlarged abdomen and weight gain: These signs typically become more prominent later in pregnancy. In the early stages, other signs, such as breast changes and nausea, are more common.

Option C - Increased appetite and weight loss: While some women may experience changes in appetite during pregnancy, significant weight loss is not a typical feature.

Option D - Lower abdominal pain and fever: These symptoms are not typical early signs of pregnancy. Lower abdominal pain can be a concerning symptom and should be evaluated separately.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a noticeable bulge in the vaginal area, along with difficulty with urination and incomplete emptying of the bladder. She has a history of multiple vaginal deliveries and reports that the symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past year. On examination, a visible bulge in the anterior vaginal wall is noted during a Valsalva maneuver. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pelvic floor exercises (Kegel exercises):

  • From the given symptoms, the diagnosis points to cystocele. The most appropriate initial management for this patient with a diagnosed cystocele, characterized by a noticeable bulge in the anterior vaginal wall and symptoms of difficulty with urination, is pelvic floor exercises, commonly known as Kegel exercises. These exercises aim to strengthen the pelvic floor muscles, which can help support the pelvic organs and alleviate symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.

  • Pelvic floor exercises involve contracting and relaxing the muscles that support the pelvic organs. They can be performed by the patient and are a non-invasive, conservative approach to manage mild to moderate cases of pelvic organ prolapse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Pessary placement : While a pessary can provide support for pelvic organ prolapse, it is often considered when conservative measures such as pelvic floor exercises do not provide sufficient relief. It may be recommended if the patient prefers a non-surgical option or if surgery is not suitable.

Option C - Surgical repair : Surgical repair may be considered if conservative measures are not effective, or in more severe cases of pelvic organ prolapse. However, it is typically reserved for cases that do not respond to non-invasive interventions.

Option D - Hormone replacement therapy : Hormone replacement therapy is not the primary management for pelvic organ prolapse. While it may address symptoms related to menopause, it does not directly address the underlying issue of pelvic floor weakness.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine examination. As part of the assessment, the healthcare provider evaluates the pelvic dimensions to determine the suitability for a vaginal delivery. On examination, the pelvis is noted to have a round inlet, a generous subpubic arch, and a wide sciatic notch. What type of pelvic shape is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gynecoid pelvis:

  • In this clinical scenario, where the pelvis has a round inlet, a generous subpubic arch, and a wide sciatic notch, the type of pelvic shape is a gynecoid pelvis. This type of pelvis is characterized by a round inlet, a wide pubic arch (greater than 90 degrees), and a wide sciatic notch. It is considered the most favorable for a vaginal delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Android pelvis : An android pelvis has a heart-shaped inlet, a narrow pubic arch, and a narrow sciatic notch. This type of pelvis is less favorable for a vaginal delivery and may be associated with increased difficulty during childbirth.

Option C - Anthropoid pelvis : The anthropoid pelvis has an oval-shaped inlet with a greater anteroposterior diameter. It is suitable for a vaginal delivery, but the shape may influence the birthing process.

Option D - Platypelloid pelvis : The platypelloid pelvis has a transversely widened but flat inlet. It is associated with challenges during labor and may require careful management

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with progressing labor. During the second stage of labor, the obstetrician decides to use the following instrument to assist with the delivery. What is the primary indication for using this instrument in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Prolonged second stage of labor:

  • The instrument in the image is a Wrigley’s forceps.

  • Wrigley's forceps are a type of obstetrical forceps designed for use during the second stage of labor when there is a prolonged delay in the descent of the fetal head despite adequate maternal expulsive efforts. The primary indication for using Wrigley's forceps is a prolonged second stage of labor.

  • Wrigley's forceps, with their unique design, are applied to the fetal head in a transverse position. This allows for effective traction and rotation, assisting in the delivery during a prolonged second stage of labor. Careful consideration and skillful application of forceps are essential to ensure the safety of both the mother and the newborn.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Fetal malpresentation: While forceps may be used for malpresentations, Wrigley's forceps are specifically designed for situations of prolonged second stage labor.

Option B - Cephalopelvic disproportion : Cephalopelvic disproportion may necessitate the use of forceps or other interventions, but Wrigley's forceps are particularly suitable for addressing prolonged second stage labor.

Option C - Maternal exhaustion : Maternal exhaustion may be a contributing factor to the decision to use forceps, but the primary indication in this scenario is the prolonged second stage of labor.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage III ovarian carcinoma following surgical exploration. The tumor is cytoreduced to minimal residual disease. The histopathology report indicates high-grade serous carcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel
Radiation therapy to the pelvic area

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel:

  • The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient with stage III ovarian carcinoma and minimal residual disease is adjuvant chemotherapy. High-grade serous carcinoma is the most common and aggressive subtype of epithelial ovarian cancer. The standard first-line chemotherapy regimen for ovarian carcinoma is a combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel.

  • Ovarian carcinoma is often diagnosed at an advanced stage, and the primary treatment involves surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. The combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel is the standard of care for adjuvant chemotherapy in advanced-stage ovarian carcinoma.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Radiation therapy to the pelvic area : Radiation therapy is not the primary treatment modality for ovarian carcinoma. It is more commonly used in other gynecological malignancies.

Option C - Hormone therapy with tamoxifen : Hormone therapy is not effective in the management of ovarian carcinoma, as these tumors are typically hormone receptor-negative.

Option D - Observation without further intervention : Given the aggressive nature of high-grade serous carcinoma and the extent of disease (stage III), observation without further intervention is not appropriate. Adjuvant chemotherapy aims to target any remaining cancer cells after surgery.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with a history of short stature, delayed puberty, and amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, low-set ears, and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. A karyotype analysis is ordered to confirm the diagnosis. What chromosomal abnormality is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 45, X:

  • This patient presents with clinical features consistent with Turner syndrome, a condition characterized by short stature, delayed puberty, and the presence of physical abnormalities such as a webbed neck, low-set ears, and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. The most common chromosomal abnormality associated with Turner syndrome is the absence of one X chromosome, resulting in a karyotype of 45,X (monosomy X).

  • Turner syndrome results from the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in females and is associated with a characteristic set of clinical features. Karyotyping, which involves the analysis of chromosomes, is crucial for confirming the diagnosis of Turner syndrome and determining the chromosomal abnormalities.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - 47,XXY : This karyotype is associated with Klinefelter syndrome, which presents with features such as tall stature, gynecomastia, and small testes, not consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Option C - 46,XX : This is a normal female karyotype and is not associated with Turner syndrome.

Option D - 47,XXX : This karyotype is associated with Trisomy X, a condition that may lead to tall stature and menstrual irregularities, but it does not present with the specific features seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a gynecology clinic in India requesting a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) at 8 weeks gestation. She has been on Combined oral contraceptive pills for 2 years with perfect adherence and no side effects. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India, what is the maximum gestational age limit within which a medical termination of pregnancy can be legally performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 24 weeks:

  • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act in India, a medical termination of pregnancy can be legally performed up to 24 weeks gestation. Up to 24 weeks, termination is allowed only under exceptional circumstances, and approval from a medical board is required.

  • The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India provides a legal framework for the safe and regulated termination of pregnancies. It aims to protect the health and well-being of women while ensuring that termination is conducted within the specified gestational limits.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 12 weeks: This is not the correct answer. While early termination is permissible, the legal limit in India is 20 weeks.

Option C - 20 weeks: This is not the correct answer. Beyond 20 weeks, termination is allowed only under specific conditions and with the approval of a medical board.

Option D - 26 weeks: This is not the correct answer. The legal limit for medical termination of pregnancy in India is 20 weeks, and terminations beyond this gestational age are exceptional and require specific approval.

questions.text: Which among the following is included in the provision of services at the logo given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - RTI/ STI services:

  • The logo of Suraksha Clinic is a white color with a red dot for reproductive and sexual health services under the NACP

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immunization services: Suraksha Clinic primarily focuses on reproductive and sexual health services; immunization services are not typically provided.

Option B - Blood transfusion safety services: Suraksha Clinic does not specifically provide blood transfusion safety services.

Option D - Diarrhea control services: Diarrhea control services are not typically part of the services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

questions.text: Expired medicines are disposed of in which of the following BMW categories?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Yellow:

  • Discarder/ Expired medicines, also known as biomedical waste or BMW, are disposed of in the yellow BMW category.
  • BMW refers to any waste generated during healthcare activities that may contain biological material and pose a risk of infection or contamination.
  • This includes anatomical waste such as human tissues, organs, body fluids, and body parts.
  • The yellow BMW category is specifically designated for the collection, storage, transportation, and disposal of these types of waste

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Red: The red BMW category typically refers to Contaminated waste that is recyclable such as Rubber and plastic tubes.

Option C - White: The white BMW category usually represents Sharps.

Option D – Blue: Blue is commonly associated with Glass and metallic implants.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, Rahul, visits his family doctor for a health check-up. The family doctor is advising Rahul on adequate nutritional requirements. Rahul tells the doctor that his weight is 65kg, is an IT professional and has a sedentary lifestyle. According to the latest NIN RDA guidelines, how many calories should Rahul take?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2110 kcal:

  • As Rahul is an IT professional, he has a sedentary life therefore the calorie to be taken by him is 2110 kcal/day according to the new energy guidelines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2130 kcal:

  • 2130 kcaL is slightly above the recommended calorie intake according to the new energy guidelines.

Option B - 3470 kcal:

  • 3470 kcal is for a heavy-working male of a standard weight of 65kgs and not for a person with a sedentary lifestyle.

Option C - 2710 kcal:

  • 2710 kcal is more than the calorie requirement for a 65KG male with a sedentary lifestyle.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about type 1 errors?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but accepted
A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug:

Type 1 Error

  • Also known as alpha error
  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Shows a false positive trial
  • Serious type of error
  • A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D:

  • They represent Type2/Beta error in which the null hypothesis is false but accepted and false negative trial is seen.

questions.text: In rural areas, one ASHA worker is assigned to a population of how many people?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – 1000:

  • An ASHA worker is a grass root level worker who is elected by a village panchayat and under the supervision of a medical officer. The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 500: This option is incorrect as The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000.

Option B - 1200: This option is incorrect as The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000.

Option C - 2500: This option is incorrect as The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000.

questions.text: A study is being conducted to understand an association between carpel tunnel syndrome and smartphone use. A group of 60 people with carpel tunnel syndrome and 60 without carpal syndrome was chosen for this study which shows 36 people who had carpel tunnel syndrome were smartphone users. what kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A case-control study:

  • In the case of the case-control study, there is an effect to cause and it starts from disease. This study is hence a case-control study.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prospective cohort study: The prospective cohort study is a cause-to-effect type of study. hence, this choice is incorrect.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study: The retrospective cohort study is a study where the effect has already occurred and it is a recall study using historical data. This is not a retrospective study.

Option D - Descriptive study: It is the Study of the distribution of health-related events & identification of characteristics. This is not a descriptive study.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about NITI aayog?

choices.text: Set up by the Planning Commission in 2010.
Responsible for framing all administrative policies.
The chairperson of framing all administrative policies is Prime Minister.
Full form: National Institution for Transforming India.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Set up by the Planning Commission in 2010:

  • NITI aayog has replaced the Planning Commission.
  • High-level expert group committee were Set up by the Planning Commission in 2010, not NITI Aayog.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D are true about niti aayog.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has recently been diagnosed with HCC. He was a worker in a groundnut oil factory for the past 25 years. He used to eat stale groundnuts that were rejected by the factory managers. Contamination of groundnuts with which of the following would have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aspergillus parasiticus:

  • Aflatoxin is caused due to groundnuts, maize, jowar gets infested with storage Fungus such as Aspergillus Flavus or Aspergillus parasiticus.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Crotalaria: Millet seeds get contaminated with Crotalaria or Jhunjhunia weeds in endemic ascites

Option C - Claviceps fusiformis: Ergotism is Caused due to the adulteration of bajra, wheat, sorghum, rye with Claviceps fusiformis.

Option D - Sanguinarine: Sanguinarine is an alkaloid found in certain plants, including bloodroot and other members of the Papaveraceae family causing Epidemic Dropsy

questions.text: Which of these vaccines do not follow open vial policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - JE:

  • Measles vaccine do not follow open vial policy

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - OPV: Follow open vial policy.

Option B - DPT: Follow open vial policy.

Option D - TT: Follow open vial policy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing in the garden when he was scratched by a street dog. The boy is rushed to the hospital immediately. On examination, There was a minor abrasion only without bleeding. What is the best management for this boy?

choices.text: Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine:

  • The patient falls under Category II according to WHO since there is no bleeding therefore she has to be administered rabies vaccine along with local wound cleaning.
  • Rabies being a lethal disease, there is no contraindication for post-exposure prophylaxis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Local wound cleaning and antibiotics: Local wound cleaning and Antibiotics are given along with vaccination.

Option B - Local wound cleaning only: Only individuals that fall under the category I need local wound cleaning.

Option D - Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins: This is the guideline for category III with no previous immunization towards rabies.

questions.text: In a prospective study comprising 10000 subjects, 6000 subjects were put on beta carotene and 4000 were not. 3 out of the ﬁrst 6000 developed lung cancer and 2 out of the second 4000 developed lung cancer. What is the interpretation of the above?

choices.text: The study design is not sufficient to draw any meaningful conclusions

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - No association:

  • Study: Cohort
  • Exposure: Beta carotene
  • Outcome: Lung cancer

  • RR = 1, no relative association between Beta Carotene and lung cancer

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Positive association: If RR>1: Positive association but in this case the RR = 1 so no relative association is established between beta carotene and lung cancer.

Option C - The study design is not sufficient to draw any meaningful conclusions: The study design is suﬃcient to draw the conclusion that RR=1 and there is no relative association.

Option D - Negative association: If RR<1: Negative association but in this case the RR=1 so no relative association is established between beta carotene and lung cancer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the hospital enquiring about contact lens. She is wearing spectacles with -3D power in bilateral eyes. It will come under which level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tertiary:

  • Social Integration is a tertiary level of prevention.
  • It is a form of rehabilitation.
  • Contact lenses/ Spectacles: They stabilize the vision and they provide visual clarity. It is limiting further damage.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primordial:

  • It is a level of prevention that is applied before the emergence of risk factors.
  • Since she is already suffering from myopia, this answer is incorrect.

Option B - Primary:

  • Primary prevention is done when The risk factor is present but the disease has not started.
  • Since she is already suffering from myopia, this answer is incorrect.

Option C - Secondary:

  • LASIK, which is a treatment for myopia, is a secondary prevention as it is a treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the dosage of iron and folic acid tablets given under the anemia mukt bharat scheme to pregnant females?

choices.text: 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic 5 days per week
60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily
50 mg Fe & 400 mcg folic acid daily

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily

  • Anemia Mukt Bharat provides 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, D are incorrect as the correct answer is 60 mg Fe & 500 mcg folic acid daily.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has delivered a healthy baby boy of 3.2kgs in a hospital. It was a normal vaginal delivery . When should she initiate breastfeeding to the baby boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Within 1 hr:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO), breastfeeding should be initiated within the first hour after birth. This is important because colostrum, the first milk produced by the mother, is rich in nutrients and antibodies that help protect the newborn from infections and diseases. It also helps to establish a strong bond between the mother and baby and stimulates milk production. Therefore, it is recommended that the primigravida initiate breastfeeding within the first hour after delivery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Within 2 hr: Waiting for 2 hours to initiate breastfeeding may cause the baby to miss out on the benefits of colostrum and delay the establishment of breastfeeding.

Option C - Within 4-6 hr: Waiting for 4-6 hours to initiate breastfeeding is not recommended as it may negatively affect the baby's health and well-being. A primigravida should initiate breastfeeding within the first hour after delivery.

Option D - Within 8-12 hr: Waiting for 8-12 hours to initiate breastfeeding is not recommended as it may negatively affect the baby's health and well-being. A primigravida should initiate breastfeeding within the first hour after delivery.

questions.text: Mary, a 35-year-old woman, attends a family gathering where her cousin, John, is present. Unbeknownst to Mary, John is in the early stages of an infectious disease. A few days after the family gathering, John starts showing symptoms, and a week later, Mary also develops symptoms. What terminology best describes the 1 week duration after which Mary becomes symptomatic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Serial interval:

  • John is the Primary case: The first case introduced in a population.
  • Mary is the Secondary case: Cases that develop on exposure to a primary case within one incubation period of a disease.
  • Serial interval: Time interval between primary and secondary case which is one week in the above question

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Incubation period: Time interval between the entry of an organism and the development of signs and symptoms.

Option C - Window period: Time interval between the entry of an organism and the detection positive on lab investigations.

Option D - Median incubation period: Time taken for 50% of cases to occur.

  • Insulin syringe has units 10 to 100 units

questions.text: Diseases under International Health Regulations include all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ebola:

  • Ebola is in the category of Diseases Under International Surveillance by WHO and not in Diseases Under International Health Regulations .

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - SARS: SARS comes under the category of Diseases Under International Health Regulations as well as Diseases Under International Surveillance by WHO

Option B - Polio: Wild Polio comes under Diseases Under International Health Regulations and Polio comes under the category of Diseases Under International Surveillance by WHO

Option C - H influenza: H influenza comes under the category of Diseases Under International Health Regulations as well as Diseases Under International Surveillance by WHO
